content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
The game is really dull; simplified to the point that even people who haven't played Zelda or FF would be turned away from sheer boredom. The game touts it's gameplay and the ability to visually travel through gaming history, through the styles of Zelda, Final Fantasy, Diablo and more. But the game leans so heavily upon it's gimmicks that when the gimmicks don't pan out, the game collapses in on itself. You start out in a Zelda-esque level and you have to unlock movement, sound, scrolling, color, art style and much more via chests. At first it brought out the nostalgia and was endearing to see someone poke fun at the absurtiy that was the sheer volume of items you had to collect and find to progress in the Zelda franchise. But when you have to unlock everything through chests like peoples, towns, even the creatures you have to fight, the joke gets old; quick. As soon as you finish collecting all the abilities and few treasures that you can collect with those newfound abilities (you collect stars that are useless and cards that can be used as a FF rip-0ff card game called Double Twin), you move to the overworld in the style of Final Fantasy. You unlock those monsters and you will trigger fight events in the overworld section and certain dungeons from that point on. Which gets annoying quick because you they happen often and I mean often. So much to the point that I can't accurately discribe the distance from the first level to the first town in pixels or time, but I can in fight events. About 7-16. And the distance between the two isn't large; the whole everworld is the size of an average FFVII dungeon.   Why did the developer do this? Simple; to balance out the time you play Zelda style and FF so it's somewhat even. To put it into perspective, There are Two towns, 3 main quest dungeons, 3 secret dungeons, 3 quest areas and one secret area. If you did strictly the main quest, the areas are all Zelda style and take a few minutes to complete, one dungeon, and the boss fight. these would take up maybe 20-30 minutes of total gameplay. The towns are FF type and you skirt through the first on in seconds maybe 5 minutes if you really explore it, you move to the dungeon ahead which takes up 5-10 minutes because of how many fights you trigger and  the only other town you skirt right through in about the same as the first town. So with dungeons and areas alone, maybe 20 minutes max you spend doing turn style based combat. If you tried to find all the collectables, you'd add on another 20-60 minutes for Zelda style combat based on if you have already unlocked the airship (which is owned by Cid, another FF rip-off). So you spend most of the game playing as a Link clone rather than you do as a FF clone, even though to travel to different levels, you have to travel through the overworld which is all FF combat. But there are so few enemy types and all but one uses melee and they spawn so often that you end up trying to run away. There is only one Diablo level (a main quest dungeon) but its another button masher that you can complete in 5 minutes or less.   The music and scenery have vary few variations. Added to the boring gameplay, this helps to further decrease any desire to continue playing.  The plot is just "Hey im a Cloud clone and you're an Aerith clone. Oh noes, its an evil being named Zephyros. Oh noes, he killt you! I am mad and you die now, Kay? The end". No effort was put into making the game interesting or good, just to look pretty.                     With that said, would I recommend this game to anyone? Only if you are some sort of Youtuber or if you use it as some sort of oddly specific social game in where you play bad games with and objective such as "Who can play the longest with out quiting from boredom" Or "Who can spot the most references"  as a drinking game. Kind of like some Youtubers who have played Mario Kart 8 and the objective was to place first. If you didn't, you would drink some sort of alcoholic beverage. That's the only time I would recommend this game. It was a great idea, just executed poorly and without any enthusiasm.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
Simple, fun, amusing and nostalgicSome games can be summarized in just a few words, Evoland is one of them. That doesn't mean it's a bad game by any stretch, but don't expect an epic journey that will last you for hours upon hours.Evoland takes us through some of the gaming we remember from our past (or have seen on YouTube, if you're not old enough), of course it is rather quick to upgrade us from very, very simple combat and graphics to more clean-looking 3D with better combat options (but certainly still not good in any way for a prolonged period of time).While people love to be nostalgic, who'd like to actually be stuck with something old?There are some amusing puzzles if you're interested in gathering all of the stars and/or cards, but it could easily be more - and that's coming from someone who is absolutely braindead when it comes to puzzles in games. In addition they have a game within the game, which is simple, yet frustrating if you get stuck with the bad cards.Overall, if you're just planning to rush through the game, you can probably do that in ~an hour (or less, I'm not sure), and as such the game might not be worth the money for you.If you however is like me, and want that little bit of nostalgic feeling while taking your time to go through the game, find all the extra bits and just be very casual about it, I would highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												Gee, I don't think I have a strong opinion either way with this game.On one hand, the references to Zelda and Final Fantasy are humorous if you've played them, particularly FF7, but otherwise, you won't understand the simple nods towards the two series. The throwback to the 80's, I believe, is interesting. It really makes you appreciate the progress that has happened in the last few decades. Honestly, it was eye-opening, as I didn't grow up in that era. It was fun seeing the game itself grow.Still, despite the humor and nostalgia, Evoland doesn't really offer anything new. The story is rather short and can be completed in 3-4 hours. I honestly do not remember the story. What I do remember is that I went through dungeons, found the hastily created boss, beat him once, then again in another form. The combat is boring; it's either slash, drop a bomb, or try to aim at moving enemies. There's nothing original about it. Combat in 3D mode is LoZ while open-world combat is classic FF mixed with 3D character models. It's basic, to sum it up.All in all, I suppose I'd recommend it. The Steam achievements are fairly easy to 100%, and if you're stuck, there are 3 wonderful guides to finding everything. However, it is rather short. Get it on sale if you're bored and have a few dollars lying around.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												Before I purchased this game I was a little skeptical due to the constant complaints about the story length and combat system, while the comments about this are slightly true this game does have its positive points one of which is the concept. The concept for this game is very unique and is executed very successfully, the game takes the player on a journey through video game history starting from the basic 2D graphics from years ago to the 3D graphics we have today. This game is not particularly difficult and could be considered a hand holder for the player but it is worth playing to watch as it shows how video games have evolved. The combat of this game is a very simple turn based system and can be rather boring at times. This game does have its flaws but at the same time it is very unique and has some good features most games lack. I rate this game 7/10. I suggest you do your research on this game before spending your money because it may not be for you, some will enjoy this game and others will not.EDITAfter playing this game a little longer I noticed some rough patches and some bad spots. When walking around you will sometimes get attcked every few seconds which gets very very annoying and the fact that each battle takes a long time to finish is an even bigger pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Another bad point is that if you are walking around and happen to die then you get sent back to a checkpoint miles away from the place you died meaning you have to go through a whole laod of♥♥♥♥♥♥again and again.

Posted: December 30, 2014
												TL;DR: Don't spend money on this.  It's extremely grindy and not very well made.  You can also play the 2D portion of the game for free as a Flash-powered game in your browser.The rest of the review:Evoland was an interesting concept that originated from a Flash-powered browser game of the same title, but the execution of this remake was rather disappointing.I was having fun with the constantly changing environment and controls and other features, but then the game slowed down.  I started having to grind my stats up to survive the random battle encounters.  I also had to grind loot to get a few of the achievements.  I wasn't seeing the constant changes any more.  I missed the fast pace of the 2D portion of the game and felt that the 3D portion of the game just wasn't as satisfying.  Eventually, I gave the game up without getting through its entire story due to lack of interest.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
 A formidable idea but a terrible realisation ( even for a 5 men team ).I had, at first, a little smile on my face while playing this game because the idea wrapping it seemed great at first.A game where you travel through gaming history while revisiting some of the most recognizable games of all time ( Zelda, Final Fantasy, Diablo ),a game where the gameplay itself evolve during your walk through the adventure, a game where...Wait, I already lied. The game stops innovating passed the first hour and starts to be redondant and to be constitute of random fights every 5 seconds;and that's the whole problem surrounding this game. The synopsis and publicity makes you think they took the best of the games it was inspired of, but it's false...They took the worse.The +:- The idea being original and meta.- The graphics evolution, from "black and white/2D/80's" graphics to pre-rendered backgrounds and 3D fights.- Some jokes and allusions may be funny...The -:- But the majority of them are just cringe worthy and could've been written by a 12 years old.- Talking about the writting, the story is absolutely.. I DON'T EVEN KNOW WHAT IT IS, BECAUSE IT'S NOT THERE!- You can basically buy two usable items ( potions and phoenix down ), a couple of swords and armors, two cards and... that's all. So much content.- Your crew will be composed of you ( a fighter ), and a mage who's only magic is heal and crystal.. *FirstShotOfWhiskey*- The music is horrible. The composer tried to copy/use FF as an influence but it's poorly done and you'll end up muting the game while listening to some Migos/Future, because these trash rappers will be candies for your ears compared to this sh*t.- The hitboxes and 3D gameplay are poorly coded, I'm pretty sure my character should've died from blunt trauma considering the number of times he took a tree right in the face.. *SecondShotOfWhiskey*- Lack of innovation after the first hour. Lack of an envy to live too.- The random encounters. Every 5 seconds. A fight. Against the same 7 ennemies. Doing the same 2 actions. Earning the same amount of XP. The same amount of Glis ( Yes, they named the currency "Glis"... ). I swear to god, those random encounters are more frequents than homeless people in big cities. - THEY NAMED THE F***IN' MONEY GLIS MAN. GLIS. I WANNA DIE, I KNOW I WANNA DIE NOW!- *DRINKTHEWHOLEBOTTLE*- *DIE*Grade: D | Try it, it can be a good game to pay for on a bundle and you may like it.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												Fantastic adventure from beginning to end. The upgrades to both technical and graphical styles you obtain throughout the game are spaced out well enough that none of them overstay their welcome. The storyline could have been tighter, but Evoland wasn't about the tale being told, it was about the journey throughout various eras in RPGs. From hack and slash to turn based, from 16-bit all the way to 3D models on a prerendered background, it all felt great, which made the game an amazing experience.If you're looking for a great story, or the best combat possible, you might want to turn away, but for everyone else that just wants a fun 2-3 hour trip down memory lane, it's a blast.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												I thought this was going to be something fairly cool and in someways it is, but it was also very disappointing and frustrating. Now that said $2.5 is incredibly cheap for a game so perhaps I did get my money's worth after 5 hours of play. The area that really upset me was the Diablo-like area in the middle of the game. (I don't know actually how near to the end this is.) I ended up stopping play after a couple hours of trying to fight against the lag and beat the boss. The battle of which would be hard even without lag. The lag was tied to specific areas in the game but unfortunately needing to be mobile meant crossing those areas eventually and it was a good likelihood you'd get slapped for 60-80% of your health before you could escape. This leads to a very lethal ending.The game itself is somewhat funny in its send up of various "Roleplaying" and Adventure gaming styles. I say that in quotes because my idea of RPGs doesn't include getting wrist strain from pounding on the keyboard. (By the way the game is played entirely on the keyboard with 0 mouse input, though it seems to have capability to interface with a gamepad.) The best parts were the transitions obtained from opening chests and the worst parts were the attempts to create a mini game that plays like a platformer with inadequate controls. I was initally attracted to the game after looking at its store page because of the image of various transitions in particular what looked like a full diabloesque inventory screen turns out to be a joke. Unfortunately the joke is on the player because it is entirely useless in the game. I don't mind jokes in games (in fact humor makes a game so much better in my opinion.) However this game takes the joke a little too far by making it at your expense. Oh the items you pick up in the Diabloesque area do nothing whatsoever and may get you killed a few times trying to get them before you realize this? OK. Ha...ha? Also a part of me thought it was a really cool idea to go from a 2d Nintendo game to a fullblown modern game with full RPG elements but alas that was merely a false impression. The last thing that makes me say "Don't buy this" is the fact that the devs seem entirely absent from the Steam forums now. The last response coming in April of 2013.

This leads to a very lethal ending.The game itself is somewhat funny in its send up of various "Roleplaying" and Adventure gaming styles. I say that in quotes because my idea of RPGs doesn't include getting wrist strain from pounding on the keyboard. (By the way the game is played entirely on the keyboard with 0 mouse input, though it seems to have capability to interface with a gamepad.) The best parts were the transitions obtained from opening chests and the worst parts were the attempts to create a mini game that plays like a platformer with inadequate controls. I was initally attracted to the game after looking at its store page because of the image of various transitions in particular what looked like a full diabloesque inventory screen turns out to be a joke. Unfortunately the joke is on the player because it is entirely useless in the game. I don't mind jokes in games (in fact humor makes a game so much better in my opinion.) However this game takes the joke a little too far by making it at your expense. Oh the items you pick up in the Diabloesque area do nothing whatsoever and may get you killed a few times trying to get them before you realize this? OK. Ha...ha? Also a part of me thought it was a really cool idea to go from a 2d Nintendo game to a fullblown modern game with full RPG elements but alas that was merely a false impression. The last thing that makes me say "Don't buy this" is the fact that the devs seem entirely absent from the Steam forums now. The last response coming in April of 2013.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												Honestly, is it the a decent RPG indie game? Kinda. Is it worth £6.99? Not really. The game manages to provide sufficient entertainment for about 3-5 hours before you beat all the content. The game progresses quickly and although the transition between a bland, black and white, 2D pixel game and a vivid, engaging 3D game is entertaining and unique at first, the experience passes by so quickly that you're left really wondering whether it was worth paying for at all.Luckily, I got this in a bundle for about 50p. It's worth that much.It's bland, it's boring but it's interesting at the same time. It's intriguing to begin with, 'evolving' through the courses of RPG gaming in an easy way but it does get tiresome quick.It's good for lazy day gaming, 2am "lmao i'm bored" and maybe a bit of curiosity, but not much else. It's very repetitive and although the minigames such as 'Double Twin' provide some sort of variety to the endless, unavoidable, random battles and irritating enemies that end up respawning every 10 seconds; it's still not much.The game has alot of potential but it just feels unfinished. Brilliant concept, great soundtrack, unlocking system is fulfilling and entertaining at first; but lacks the excecution to turn a great concept into a great game.6/10 for a short indie game with a good soundtrack.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												"Evoland – A Short Story of Adventure Video Games Evolution" is a well made game that does exactly what it set out to do: in just one game you will experience the evolution of adventure video games. Since the difficulty level overall is very low, this can be recommended for two types of people: those with nostalgia and those new to the genre or games in general - seasoned players won't find it challenging and will spend the most of their time trying to find all the chests in the game. For me, the great thing about this game is, that developers put in many tropes of the genre, also acknowledging the different eras of video game development - sometimes an advancement comes at a price and sometimes an advancement is, in retrospect, not that advancing but a necessary step forward.Altough there are two main influences (namely The Legend of Zelda series and the FInal Fantasy series), there are nods to others as well.One could nitpick that some steps and/or features have been left out, but that's beyond the point - the game does, what it does, well.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												Evoland is an interesting game concept. Accumulating game features as you go via chests or other means is enjoyable for a while, but after it slows down and stops you're not left with much. In some areas there is a tedious and rudimentary Final Fantasy battle system which will always threaten you with random death if you're not careful. In others there's a decent Zelda style adventure full of tedious dungeons but with inventive puzzles (especially the later one's). It's not an overly long game, but I feel like I would have gotten the point of the game with about 30% less overworld travel and maybe getting bombs earlier. Completionists be warned, you'll want to keep very close track of where you need to come back to later, as there are things you need to come back to in the endgame to get in seemingly every area. Also, the Final Fantasy card game makes an appearance, and I'm even less inclined to play it here than I was in FF8.Overall it's hard not to recommend Evoland. I had fun playing it, but replay value isn't high. My completion percentage at the end of the game was 92.9% and I didn't feel compelled to go out and get the last 2 or 3 things I missed in random chests.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Evoland explores the evolution of the Zelda and Final Fantasy games. The game starts out in Gameboy monochromatic and continues to 8-bit, 16-bit, PSX styled blocky 3D, and finally hi def 3D. The dungeons are explored in the same fashion of the old school Zelda games while the overworld aspect has random battles and leveling up. The entire game is filled with parodies pertaining to not only the genres but tropes in Zelda and Final Fantasy specificially. A great game that will only take 3-4 hours but will completely be worth it!

												A game that pays homage to many great rpgs from the past. As you go through the game it 'evolves' through the stages that rpgs went through. It often does this using parody which makes the game funny and enjoyable.The biggest problems for me were it being easy and too short. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												Evoland is a journey through the first few generations of video games. Starting with simple black and white 8-bit graphics that resemble the earliest GameBoys, it slowly evolves into Nintendo 64 era features. Each time the player opens one of many treasure chests scattered across the worlds, new graphical, musical, or sound effects are "unlocked." In this way, the game slowly progresses through the history of action/adventure video games. Obviously inspired by classics like The Legend of Zelda, Final Fantasy, and Diablo, this game appeals to fans of those games, like myself. Highlights of the game include the unique evolution style, decent music (though sometimes overly repetitive), and a great homage to classic games. On the negative side, the game was a bit too long for me, but only because I searched for every secret room and hidden items. So, without the side-questing, I am sure the game would have been less of a drag. There was included as well in the game a side mini-game, called Double Twin. This was a basic card game twist of tic-tac-toe. Again, an interesting idea, but only good for a few plays, not for prolonged play-time. This also marks the first time that I have gained all the achievements for a game on Steam... No reward for that except a little self-pride...Review originally published on https://brockpattison.blogspot.com/

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												[Overall rating 2/5]I must begin with saying that when I first heard about this game I couldn't wait to playit, but when I finally found out my bf bought it in a bundle, the only reason I actually played for the full 4 hours was because I spent 1 of them searching for more interesting content I were convinced must be there somewhere because of the good reviews. I didn't find it. The beginning is fun and it felt accomplishing earning new dimensions and mecanics, until you get the 3D graphics, after this point the gameplay grows more teadious for every new stage and the controls are imprecise. This was for me very frustrating. I continued playing only because I waited for it to be as fun as in the beginning  (the first 20 min) again.I found the the Final Fantasy battles charming and fun at first, but also this got old quickly because of the low variation of attacks, enemies and characters, and when you finally gain new attacks the character choise immideatly shrinks, and guess what more? You no longer have any relevant battles in this style of gaming to use them in. Not. Worth. It.The boss battles are unimaginative and boring, ESCPECIALLY the last one which I completed first after a hiatous of a few weeks because it was so teadious and the controls so bad that I couldn't bring myself to finish it. When I finally did, it was only because I wanted to give a fair review.Except for the first, Zelda-esque part of the game, the absolutly only part I enjoyed was the in game card game, which I also spent about 20 min with. If that was released as a android game I probably would buy it. Would I now buy Evoland at full price? No. As a homage or satire, it's perfectly fine, but maybe at the price of a few euro.

												I usually hate indie games because they're bad cash-ins without anything interesting and made without any real heart on the developer's end. They're shallow and incredibly not worth the bang for the buck.This time, I found something not awful. Honestly it's fun and interesting if short. A series of RPG tropes and technology through the years. Plenty of decent references but then there's all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ "look @ me i'm a 90s kid guys do you remember the 90s please guys remember the 90s with me" moments with parts of the in-game text. Gameplay is based around what era of RPG you are in. There's an achievement every five steps, but they're either incredible miniscule or they actually affect the gameplay in certain areas. It's not pretentious, but there are some EHPIK MEEMAYS here n' there. One of the few Greenlight games with a not-terrible concept.

content:

												If you are a child of the 80s and 90s and need a nostalgia trip stop reading now and buy this game. Everyone else? The gameplay is short. It has no replayability. It is not innovative except for the fact that it tells the story of the history of gaming and shows how the technology of gaming has progressed over the decades. So the question is, does it sound worth it to you?I recommend this game to anyone that wants to see the story of how we went from the years after the collapse in 1983 upt and (and including) Diablo 3. How the technology has progressed. And experience some of the type of gameplay that you saw in Zelda and Final Fantasy titles. But purely as a game? No, probably not worth it.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2013
												For any fan of classic retro RPG games, ranging from Zelda: Link's Awakening through Seiken Densetsu and Final Fantasy up to Diablo, Evoland is worth checking out. The game starts out with a 4-bit Gameboy feel and slowly evolves as you play through unlocking different aspects of the genre. The sentence "You got XYZ" will become very familiar very quickly, and I say "very quickly" both because the game is short and evolves as a quick pace, which is one of my gripes. While the trip down nostalgia lane is very welcome, some of the game feel is progressed very rapidly (from one screen to another I had changed to 8-bit colour, then bumped almost immediately up to 16-bit). The other issue with the game is that later on, once you have unlocked the turn based battle, XP, and a second character, the pace gets very tiresome. XP is awarded, but levelling up is pointless toward the end of the game since the final boss battle gives you a limited 12 HP hit counter anyway, GP awarded is useful to buy only a handful of items such as Potions which I never used because my secondary character has infinite MP and heal. At that point, random encounters become a time filler with no real reward, and just become a tedious chore to get out of the way.If taken as a stroll through RPG history, as more of a story or interactive showcase than a game, it works, and I found it enjoyable on the whole.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												[Overall rating 2/5]I must begin with saying that when I first heard about this game I couldn't wait to playit, but when I finally found out my bf bought it in a bundle, the only reason I actually played for the full 4 hours was because I spent 1 of them searching for more interesting content I were convinced must be there somewhere because of the good reviews. I didn't find it. The beginning is fun and it felt accomplishing earning new dimensions and mecanics, until you get the 3D graphics, after this point the gameplay grows more teadious for every new stage and the controls are imprecise. This was for me very frustrating. I continued playing only because I waited for it to be as fun as in the beginning  (the first 20 min) again.I found the the Final Fantasy battles charming and fun at first, but also this got old quickly because of the low variation of attacks, enemies and characters, and when you finally gain new attacks the character choise immideatly shrinks, and guess what more? You no longer have any relevant battles in this style of gaming to use them in. Not. Worth. It.The boss battles are unimaginative and boring, ESCPECIALLY the last one which I completed first after a hiatous of a few weeks because it was so teadious and the controls so bad that I couldn't bring myself to finish it. When I finally did, it was only because I wanted to give a fair review.Except for the first, Zelda-esque part of the game, the absolutly only part I enjoyed was the in game card game, which I also spent about 20 min with. If that was released as a android game I probably would buy it. Would I now buy Evoland at full price? No. As a homage or satire, it's perfectly fine, but maybe at the price of a few euro.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												I only found out about this game in the past week or so, and so after a bit of rummaging around, i gave it a go. Best idea i've had for a while now.This game is a very short, very sweet little homage to games such as Final Fantasy and Zelda, and it does a capital job. The game starts with you only allowed to go right in a 2d line with no music, no sound, no anything. But through getting various things in chests (the left key, sound effects, a storyline, etc) you see in front of you, how the RPG and Adventure genres have evolved over the years, hence the name. It's got it all- your hero-looking person, turn-based battling, life gauges, random encounters (lord help) and loads of pointless collectible stars. Eventually, you even get a bit of a Diablo segment, except it pokes fun at huge aspects of it- an inventory's worth of gear that all does squat, (e.g 'Turns you into a dragon. 12 months cooldown.') to the lag-inducing masses of enemies, all of which apart from the wizards are decimated by mere button-mashing.This game also has an outstanding soundtrack. It is just beautiful. From the catchy tune of the battle theme, to the emotional tune of when  Zephyros kills Kaeris  to the final boss theme, which is one of the most incredible fight themes i have heard to date.I have one major problem with this game, though, and it's that the game is really short. I've played the game once through and it took about two hours. Still, the sequel may have a longer playtime and much more fleshed-out story, but it still is one of the most charming indies i've played. In this case, size isn't everything.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												Cute series of winks to RPG developments in history. It's nice to see the game evolve visually as you unlock stuff, and there's a small puzzle element that requires you to switch environments. The quality of the experience varies a lot though:- They actually included annoying elements from the games they're parodying, such as no dungeon minimap, way too many random encounters and a stupidly hard boss battle.- Controls are bad, directional pad not responding well using an Xbox360 pad- 3d animations are bad- All gameplay elements are hastily implemented and are worse than what they imitate... it can only be pardoned if you're here for the joke, but if you expect a serious RPG expect disappointment.- The humor is so-soOverall I kind of enjoyed it, but I got annoyed several times at the game and was about to quit just before they brought in a game-changing element. At least it's short, so it shouldn't overstay its welcome too much.Oh yeah, and if you're into that you can backtrack once you're almost at the final boss to collect stars (useless) and cards (to play a minigame). I'll pass, but I appreciate that they put in the effort for those who like that.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												A very entertaining idea for a game. Going through the "evolution" of games from nice old 8-bit to some 3D graphics (and across multiple genres of gameplay) was really fun to me.The game can become a little boring for a while because it gets a little grindy, but old-school RPGs are indeed that way, so I guess you cannot really fault them for keeping to the source material.Story-wise, the game is a cliche and not that interesting other than to giggle at various events. Graphics-wise, I really enjoyed the transformations and did not care whether I was seeing the best graphics ever (particularly the 3D RPG graphics). Music-wise, the game has interesting melodies along your journey. And gameplay-wise, it fits the various genres that it goes through.All in all, a pretty interesting game to spend your time on.

Literally if you like only 2 Hit Damage On a Monster go ahead keep doing it. The company even resorts to having an exact replica of a statue of BOWSER from Mario in the game. Um how did they sneak that in and Nintendo didnt notice it? Seriously Nintendo needs to know about this PRONTO! I honestly had more higher hopes for this game as it was suppose to take like a Zelda and FinalFantasy game instead though the very end of the game is gonna leave you thinking "Wow I spent 3 almost 4 hours on a game and beat it with no problem". And thats it its very short, no special endings, and just pretty bland. If you buy this game get it when its on sale at like $5 or lower. Otherwise if you see this for higher than $9 dont get it. It will leave a little bad taste in your mouth. 5/10

content:
Posted: June 13, 2013
												Wow.  This left me smiling and laughing throughout the entire game.  The premise is simple -- starting from simple right-only movement, and progress through RPG history (circa ~2000's).  There's so much overlapping and nuanced inclusion of so many RPG defining moments in this game that it left me thinking about those old RPG's as I played through this game.Nostalgia is one hell of a drug; and this game oozes it.For most RPG players, this game is a trigger mechanism to remember your favorite moments of RPG history, from many, many games.If you've played through Final Fantasy, Zelda, Ultima, Dragon's Quest, Secret of Mana, Diablo... you must play this game.If you haven't, you really need to play through all of those series to enjoy this game.5/5

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												This was a lot of fun! I bought it for $3 during the steam sale. Having played it, it was worth every penny. To review in one sentence: Evoland is short and sweet.It's basically a trip down 90's RPG memory lane. In the game you get upgrades. Each upgrade improves the game. For instance, there's the '256 color' upgrade, the '3d' upgrade, and even an "HD Texture pack" upgrade. I won't spoil any more, but there are some clever ways the game gives you to make itself more fun.As for the gameplay, it's changing so often that once you get the reference and appreciate it's implementation, it's on to the next innovation. This is not a bad thing.Lastly, there is a minor technical issue. In order to play the game with a gamepad (highly recommended) you have to set the executable and one other file to run in compatibility mode with windows 7 and run as administrator. This will hose your hours played in steam.If you're at least 25 years old, there be good gaming here.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2013
												I usually hate indie games because they're bad cash-ins without anything interesting and made without any real heart on the developer's end. They're shallow and incredibly not worth the bang for the buck.This time, I found something not awful. Honestly it's fun and interesting if short. A series of RPG tropes and technology through the years. Plenty of decent references but then there's all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ "look @ me i'm a 90s kid guys do you remember the 90s please guys remember the 90s with me" moments with parts of the in-game text. Gameplay is based around what era of RPG you are in. There's an achievement every five steps, but they're either incredible miniscule or they actually affect the gameplay in certain areas. It's not pretentious, but there are some EHPIK MEEMAYS here n' there. One of the few Greenlight games with a not-terrible concept.

So the question is, does it sound worth it to you?I recommend this game to anyone that wants to see the story of how we went from the years after the collapse in 1983 upt and (and including) Diablo 3. How the technology has progressed. And experience some of the type of gameplay that you saw in Zelda and Final Fantasy titles. But purely as a game? No, probably not worth it.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												Evoland is a journey through the first few generations of video games. Starting with simple black and white 8-bit graphics that resemble the earliest GameBoys, it slowly evolves into Nintendo 64 era features. Each time the player opens one of many treasure chests scattered across the worlds, new graphical, musical, or sound effects are "unlocked." In this way, the game slowly progresses through the history of action/adventure video games. Obviously inspired by classics like The Legend of Zelda, Final Fantasy, and Diablo, this game appeals to fans of those games, like myself. Highlights of the game include the unique evolution style, decent music (though sometimes overly repetitive), and a great homage to classic games. On the negative side, the game was a bit too long for me, but only because I searched for every secret room and hidden items. So, without the side-questing, I am sure the game would have been less of a drag. There was included as well in the game a side mini-game, called Double Twin. This was a basic card game twist of tic-tac-toe. Again, an interesting idea, but only good for a few plays, not for prolonged play-time. This also marks the first time that I have gained all the achievements for a game on Steam... No reward for that except a little self-pride...Review originally published on https://brockpattison.blogspot.com/

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Evoland explores the evolution of the Zelda and Final Fantasy games. The game starts out in Gameboy monochromatic and continues to 8-bit, 16-bit, PSX styled blocky 3D, and finally hi def 3D. The dungeons are explored in the same fashion of the old school Zelda games while the overworld aspect has random battles and leveling up. The entire game is filled with parodies pertaining to not only the genres but tropes in Zelda and Final Fantasy specificially. A great game that will only take 3-4 hours but will completely be worth it!

												A game that pays homage to many great rpgs from the past. As you go through the game it 'evolves' through the stages that rpgs went through. It often does this using parody which makes the game funny and enjoyable.The biggest problems for me were it being easy and too short. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												A wonderfully inventive game, Evoland features a mixture of game play between the Legend of Zelda series and the Final Fantasy series. You start out with only black and white, 2 dimensional game play. You unlock colors, graphics, 3 dimensional gameplay, sound and sound quality, gameplay features and basically everything to do with a game by finding the different and many chest found throughout the game. It also features (true to the Final Fantasy spirit), a mini card game within the game. You can find or buy cards to play it. A fun plot (once you unlock the storyline as you do everything else including basic movement), it keeps you entertained for hours. You also unlock the ability of save points found scattered throughout the land, health (which when in Zelda mode shows as hearts in the upper right hand side of the screen). When in Final Fantasy open world exploration mode with radom encounters, battles play out as made famous by the Final Fantasy series up to Final Fantasy IX. More unlocks and fun than you can imagine, the gameplay is highly addictive and keeps you smiling. Dungeons also unfold where you must move blocks onto pressure pads to open gates or put you in trap rooms where you must defeat all the monsters within to escape, and mazes unfold as well. I could not for the price range recommend many games as highly as this one for absolutely any gamers collection. On a scale of 1 to 10, 1 being horrible and 10 being the most awesome game of all time, this one would rank as a solid 9. Well worth the investment.

												I started playing this game giggling like a little school girl. This is such an amazing concept that I can't believe this is the first weve seen of it (to my knowledge). Which is why it pains me that this game just doesn't 'evolve'... hehe.... into what it could be.The first 45 minutes-hour have a lot of promise as you unlock new technologies and cycle through game modes... but after that it trickles out new unlocks and doesn't really go anywhere. It turns into a 'Bah-bies first Zelda clone'. I have got to be frank.... I don't like Zelda (Early titles). The gameplay just didn't do anything for me. I much prefer the strategy of turn based combat. Speaking of....There is 0 depth to this game. From the combat to the story. During turn based sections you have yourself and a girl character. The girl is the mage who only starts with heal and you a basic attack. Then, by about half way through the game she finally gets 1 magic attack that does the same damage as your sword attack and you get nothing. Thats it. Even on the Zelda side of things nothing evolves past the early Zelda titles. You get a sword, bombs, and arrows.The story is throw away.The humour seems to just consist of 'Epic Movie' type refrences. You are a lucky lucky person if you dont know what that means....Nothing is really done with the concept of evolving through the generations. I would love to see a larger scaled game maybe by some tested devs who could take this concept and just go nuts. I freaking love this idea and I hope to see it around again. Kudos to the devs for thinking of it but I really wish you would hahve developed it more.Oh, also the game is only 3 hours long. I just kind of gave up half way in because I can't play old school style Zelda without a controller and I just couldn't get controller support to work. : /Update: I noticed a You-tuber I like had a full playthrough of this so I decided to watch the rest of it to see what I missed. I have to say Im happy I gave up when I did.The game turns into a diablo like (using that phrase lightly) game after I quit. Again like with the rest of the game there is no depth to it. You pick up loot that doesnt even effect anything and you are still using the combat mechanics from zelda. You get gold drops but gold is useless and cant actually be used for anything.The story is laughable. Its so crap. I can't imagine what the devs thought when they cobbled that mess together. Maybe it was the day before release and all the writers has hangovers so they got the janitor who played an rpg once like 20 years ago to finish the story for them.You get a map finally during this section but nothing else happens. The boss fight here is just as lame and uninspiered as the rest.Then you fight the final boss and finally get a second attack for the main hero which is on a 4 minute cooldown and is only used once. The boss is in 2 sections. You get beat for the first fight and your compainion dies *spoilers but who cares*. You get an airship to get to where the boss moved to because reasons, and fight in a zelda type boss fight. Then credits roll. Thats it.I can't understand how they were able to think of such an awesome concept for the game but didnt have a single good idea other than that. I pray I see this idea take shape from devs who are actually talented.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												Summary: A game you'll likely play once, but enjoy every nostalgic minute of the roughly 3 hour storyline. Hours of fun: 3 hoursSuggested Retail Value: $5Graphics: 6/10Voice-acting: 6/10Music/SFX: 6/10Uniqueness: 6/10First Play-through Experience: 7/10Replay Value: 5/10Evoland is a fun game for anyone who has a love for old-school RPGs, an interest in how RPGs have changed over the last couple of decades, or just want to experience an adventure that spans several generations of RPG all in one sitting. If that's true of you then I doubt you'll regret buying it, and you can probably expect to want to talk to others about it. I doubt anyone would regret paying $5 or less for this, though there may be a small number of gamers who would feel the story was too short to justify spending more. It's likely to wake the little kid in you, and will probably make you want to play through your library of "classics", but I doubt you'll want to play through the game a second time just to find all the "Hidden Stars". But maybe that's just because I dislike collection quests, and so completely ignored that aspect of the game (which you can easily do!).

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												After spending hours trying to find the upgrade that made the gameplay fun and interesting, and combing through a walkthrough, I was dismayed to learn no such upgrade exists.I gave this game way too many opportunities to redeem itself, and it never did. I saw it in the store, and it looked nice. A friend got it and played it. Told me it wasn't worth my money. So that wouls have been the end of it, but I think I ended up with a copy froma  Humble Bundle or something. It sat in my library for about a year, until, bored one day, I fired it up.It starts out in the standard manner for this sort of game - you start with one direction of movement, then unlock the others. Cheesy, but the earliest games were reestricted to lateral movement and the like, so I was game. Up until you pick up the transition from grayscale to 16 colors. The grayscale setup was a bit of a stretch, since graphics never really worked that way for early games (not counting  handhelds), but I was being lenient. 16 color made it clear that the designers had never really looked at the graphics for anyhting earlier than Playstation era. Even if the system could handle so many colors on a single sprite, it means the main character permanently occupies half the available pallette of the world. (Fun fact: Mega Man had to be composed of two sprites to support his whopping total of 5 colors).Clearly, the developers were aware of how much they messed up 16 colors, because they jumped to 256 colors almost immediately. As noted above, though, they never did the same for the gameplay. In fact, they actively made the gameplay worse than the old games they claim to emulate - as part of a cheap gimmick, you get an upgrade that unbinds you from the grid. While that should be a good thing, it means you're out of alignment with enemies more often than not. And 95% of the game still uses a grid, so you're not getting much benefit from it. Up to and including gaps between trees like the cute barrier they put in place for you to bypass - nearly indistinguishable from the normal grid barriers, and exceedingly rare.Problems like this pop up so often that it becomes clear that the immediate jump from 16 colors to 256 wasn't any sort of self-awareness; they want the game to be "pretty" as fast as possible. They take way too long to add a health bar to progress beyong 1 hit = death. They add a "Loading" screen that costs 5000 GP to get rid of - from random fights that drop 100-200 GP each (not that there's much worthwhile to spend your money on, but it's still a stupid aproach).Things start to get some hope when they drop you into a Diablo-style section, but that's msotly padding and an excuse for cheap jokes - back to the status quo after that. With one exception - you get a combo chain ability (because we all know that Diablo invented the combo chain).All in all, it starts off with some promise, but the hope for it to get better gradually fades. On top of that, 2/3 of the way through the game, you've unlocked pretty much eveything, and from that point on, it may as well be called "Spinal Clam SE: Heaven". Except that still gives too much credit to the story writing.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2016
												It's a cute little game with a very cool concept -- start with a bare-bones, barely even playable adventure game circa the early 80s, and gradually unlock upgrades to the game's engine until you're playing essentially a reasonably polished PS1 RPG.  There have been Flash games such as Upgrade Complete that have toyed with this concept but Evoland's the first one I know of to apply it to the action-adventure/RPG genre.Sadly, there are problems on the other side of the coin; the first area is charming and innovative, and a bit past that is still fairly amusing, but it quickly becomes apparent that with a tiny handful of exceptions, the game spent the majority of its gimmick early on.  Large swaths of the (admittedly tiny) game after that starting area are simply fairly boring treks through generic locales, swapping back and forth between ultra-simple Zelda and ultra-simple Final Fantasy segments back and forth, with Ys-Lite style bosses and one singular area that offers a fun genre shift into hack-n'-slash.  There are also various smaller annoyances to add on, such as... - The random battle rate for the RPG sections and especially the overworld is way, way, WAY too high; - A few enemies (especially the wasps) dodge attacks too often, and even spells!  I see no reason why missing should have even been a mechanic in this game at all; - There's no way to use your healing magic or items outside of battle; - The healing fountains/inns are ridiculously few, far between and quite out of the way, even for such a small game; - As far as I can tell, there's absolutely NO USE to the collectible 'stars' you find throughout the game, except a pointless achievement; - LIkewise, the collectible cards only serve to let you play an extremely bare-bones ripoff of Triple Triad from Final Fantasy 8, with no rewards earned for winning even the highest difficulty except, again, a pointless achievement; - In said card game you can't organize decks and it picks at random from all cards you own, meaning it would be most efficient to only collect 5 of the strongest cards and no others, though the minigame's easy enough that it doesn't really matter; - There's really no story and not even much humor or charm in the dialogue -- it's VERY cut and dry.The game probably would have also benefitted greatly by either being even shorter and to-the-point but filled with as much love and care as the first area was throughout, or with a bit more length and substance to more fully flesh out the slightly grander ideas presented.Still, though, it's small and harmless enough to be worth checking out, and when it does do well it's really great.  Could have been better, but definitely recommended for the small time commitment and asking price considering how cool the ideas presented are.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
Product received for free
												I played this game on a whim while looking through my friends games in the family share. This game brought back so many fond memories of playing Diablo, Final Fantasy VII-IX, and even Shining force. If you grew up with older games then you owe it to yourself to give this game a try, if not then see what you missed. The plot of the game was 90% parodies of older games but you shouldn't come to this game looking for plot, that's not what this game is about, it's about nostalgia and it nails its goal. I also loved all the snarky jokes they threw in during each evolution. I fully plan to buy Evoland II and I hope they make a III. Enjoy a slice of history (and if you don't want Final Fantasy VII ruined play it first, though at this point who hasn't played it or had it ruined?)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
Fun, creative game with some serious difficulty curvesEvoland is a creative game that does face a few problems. I loved the idea, starting from 8-bit, and transitioning all the way into 3D graphics. It is not limited to the graphics, and evolves as it goes along, fitting the evolutions into the story. It throws in turn-based battles, save points, and nearly any general advancement along the way. However, while all of this is cool, it has a few problems.It's too short; it only has about four hours of gameplay not counting:The difficulty curves. Some areas are waaay too hard, and can seriously hinder progress.Leveling up only counts toward turn based battles. The hard areas are a great example of this. Plus, you don't level up in these areas.Many evolutions don't stay around for very long, or aren't used very much.Overall: 7/10, still recommended to try

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												Evoland was a fun little diversion from all of the mainstream games that I've been playing lately. It provided me with some fond memories of old school games, though it came with a few flaws. Definitely worth your time, but don't expect to fill your weekend with just this game.Good:The action turn-based combat system was very solid.There was plenty of collectables that were hidden decently well.The story did not drag on as some older adventure/RPG games tend to do.The later half of the game looks absolutely amazing.There was a fun little card based minigame that directly tied into the collectables.The Diablo inspired section was very fun.Seeing the game portrayed in all the different art styles was very fun.Bad:The Zelda inspired combat sections have wildly fluxuating difficulty.The adventure segments lacked any real puzzles.The party size was very limited compared to most RPGs.The game felt a little short, especially for an adventure/RPG game. I beat it in approximately five hours and while I didn't obtain all collectables, I still managed to beat the game with 90% completion.The card minigame's harder difficulties relied a little too heavily on RNG rather than strategy. Despite this, I still managed to beat all dificulties without collecting all the cards.The end of the game didn't really have a solid payoff, relying more on presumed emotional ties rather than a solid conclusion.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Take a trip down nostalgia lane as this game presents to you the evolution of RPGs since the days of 'black & white' to the infamous turn-based battle system and beyond. It's a game that pays homage to how RPGs have evolved and even pokes fun at the various tropes surrounding this particular genre of gaming.As a proper game, this title falls short (literally). It's only about 4 hours long if you bother exploring and playing around a little. However, that being said, this game was made to solely sell on its ability to humour the genre and to suffocate players with its nostalgia. You'll find references to Final Fantasy, Zelda and more.Taking into account on how this game was made to sell, I can only recommend it based quite heavily on its gameplay, which for the most part, is relatively fun. I'm not one to enjoy turn-based battles but if you like that, expect quite a bit of it. Outside of that though, the real-time combat is actually quite fun albeit simple. But, as the saying goes, it's good and simple.Ultimately, it's a short but sweet experience. This game is targeted solely towards RPG gamers and if you are not one of them, I would suggest you skip it. I do not recommend picking this up at full price but when it drops down to below half, I don't see why you shouldn't spend on it.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
Product received for free
												I played this game on a whim while looking through my friends games in the family share. This game brought back so many fond memories of playing Diablo, Final Fantasy VII-IX, and even Shining force. If you grew up with older games then you owe it to yourself to give this game a try, if not then see what you missed. The plot of the game was 90% parodies of older games but you shouldn't come to this game looking for plot, that's not what this game is about, it's about nostalgia and it nails its goal. I also loved all the snarky jokes they threw in during each evolution. I fully plan to buy Evoland II and I hope they make a III. Enjoy a slice of history (and if you don't want Final Fantasy VII ruined play it first, though at this point who hasn't played it or had it ruined?)

content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												The protagonist is called Clink, and he's shortly joined by a girl with magical powers called Kaeris, who has an uncle with an airship called Sid. And they find a legendary sword called Claud's Sword, which looks like a ♥♥♥♥ing Buster Sword... you see where this is going?A game strictly aimed to the "US GAMERS AMIRITE" crowd, heavily seasoned with cringey references to other games and the kind of overused memes that Reddit drove into the ground back in 2012, it forces you to unlock many basic features as you explore a generic JRPG map trying to figure out what exactly is the purpose with the game. In just the very first map of the game, you go through several graphical changes which don't exactly change the quality of the game. They don't teach you anything historically significant, they're just there to make you go "wow, the EVOlution of videogames".Sadly, the spritework even at its pre-3D apex was nothing to write home about, as everything looked flat and unispired, with no hints at having put any effort into some basic shading. Visually, the game shines once the 3D kicks in and textures become sharper and better defined.Unfortunately for Evoland, a game cannot be carried alone on graphical artstyle. And the game itself is pretty boring. You constantly switch between random encounters with an ATB permanently set to Wait, and a bad action RPG mode that feels stiff and overly simplistic.Had this game focused on fleshing out every mode and building upon it with each graphical iteration to make it an increasingly complex game, I'd recommend it wholeheartedly. I had honestly though that this is the direction the game was supposed to go in. But, as it stands, it feels like a final high school project by someone very talented but with little experience into what makes a game good besides aesthetics.If you MUST get it, I'd recommend getting it heavily discounted on sale, or wait for it to come up in a 1 dollar bundle making sure you direct all your money to charity.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												The trailer makes this game seem much more inspiring than it in actuality is: Although the retro, evolving playstyle is unique and at first nostalgic, it's fairly clear that the developers did not have sufficient resources at their disposal to finish gradually updating the graphics to present-day, and as such, about halfway through the game, the evolution prompty stops. This is besides the fact that the progression is painfully general, at some points changing almost nothing and at others skipping whole years of the industry's steps - I'm sorry, but the change from 2d to 3d did not happen overnight, as this game seems to depict.I fancy myself as being able to appreciate games that go to lengths to make a statement, but beyond establishing it, this game does not really go any further. The game lacks a substantial or original plot, has a fairly limited interface, is laughably short, gets repetitive quickly, and has absolutely no replay value.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												This game is cute and quaint, which is alright I guess; but, the problem is this game is cute and quaint.Challenge element to the game is just hovering above 0.  Sure, there are little puzzles that take a little thinking, but this one won't wear you out and if you have the slightest bit of tenacity you can probably finish the game in less than 2hrs.  A lot of people will tell you that this is a great portrayal of RPG games from FF1 & old Zelda to FF9 & newer Zelda.... and it is, if you want the most general feel of those games.  The problem is that there is no real feeling of accomplishment in this game, due to the lack of challenge, lack of any clear story, and shortness of the game itself.   The final achievements to strive for, collecting all the items and money ("glis" based off the FF series) don't seem worth the striving.  The null-challenge battles you'd have to go through to save up 50K glis would be more annoying than satisfying, plus there are NO ITEMS in the game to spend your money on.  The char's lvling up means nothing.  If you're looking for the Diablo-like play in the game, don't get your hopes up because the one little map that is supposed to be Diablo-esque provides as little as the rest of the game--after all, the equipment and gold serve no purpose... there's no character building anywhere in this game.  The one cool feature was the challenge element of going forward and backward in time to circumvent obstacles.     This game is more like a short film to annoy you and make you laugh than it is an actual game.  If you are judging this by some other perspective than a game, then maybe it's okay.  However, if I had access to a time machine, I most definitely would go back in time and not buy this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												A Zelda and Final Fantasy fan love letter.This title is pretty short and full of RPG in-jokes, and that's part of its charm of course, but the real accomplishment here is the standout blend of nearly every genre defining aspect of retro (and in some ways even modern) RPGs.Evoland starts in a very gameboy-like monochrome pixelated setting, and you start by unlocking the arrow keys for movement, and then the scrolling screens so you can move to different areas, and then enemies, and then a weapon to fight said enemies. Get a little further still and you'll unlock a color display! Wow color!The unlockable everything aspect sort of reminded me of Half Minute Hero, though thankfully Evoland doesn't have that title's frantic "time is running out constantly hurry hurry hurry!" methodology killing its fun factor.It's neat to look back on the progression and see how things evolve as you play, and it's a fairly good reminder really to the way games of old have matured over the decades.I'd say the two plain-as-day obvious biggest influences on Evoland are the early Zelda titles, and in particular, Final Fantasy 7. However there are a number of other small references here and there to others as well: Secret of Mana, Final Fantasy 4 and 6, Final Fantasy 8 just to name a few that I was easily able to recognize.The story, well there hardly is one, and again, see Zelda/FF7 for the majority of parallels, sometimes downright ripoffs honestly. Still the concept remains interesting throughout the relatively short campaign (it took me about 8 hours for 100% completion).The fact that you don't have to sink 100+ hours into it is actually welcome. It gets the point across and manages to be enjoyable without requiring a month's worth of your spare time.If you are a fan of older RPGs and indie titles you'll definitely find something to like here. Just having multiple battle systems and graphical presentations in a single game and having it work well together is reason enough to give it a try. Not to mention the trip down memory lane.

												I thoroughly enjoyed the experience offered up by Evoland.  It is basically a trip down memory lane, celebrating RPG's from as far back as the C64, up to the Wii U (Sorry, i don't count PS4/Xbox one, so far).  The story is about a young boy who quickly develops as the story progresses, finding the stereotypical sword, then the ability to 'Evolve' his skills.  In summary, he has to save a small village from the darkness, and as you can tell from my playtime it is a very short game.If you feel that its asking price is too high, get it on a hunble bundle.  For me, I'd say its just right.  The experience made me smile and remember when games were made by gamers with passion, not AAA corporations milking the proverbial cash cow that is first person shooters with a lick of paint and a few extra guns.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												This is a fun nostalgia trip. Lots of the game is obviously taken from Zelda and Final Fantasy games, but what's been taken is the good stuff. The game feels rewarding thanks to finding upgrades to the game quite often (upgrades come from better graphics, audio, and gameplay elements). The acheivements are challenging and add value to the gameplay. All in all, a good game.I will say, though, that the hit detection isn't perfect with some attacks and enemies, and the controls are a little clunky at times. Also, the other minor annoyance is the fact that once you get the zoom in animation for finding items, you open the chest slightly off from where the audio plays. The story isn't exactly original, but I don't think it was supposed to be. These are mostly nitpicks, though. Once you get used to the controls, the game is well worth playing.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												Evoland is basically every bad old RPG rolled up into one. Boring enemies, boring combat, excuse plot, character who dies who you just don’t care about at all (or indeed, care about any of the characters at all), ect.The game is meant to poke fun at old RPGs, including Final Fantasy, Dragon Quest, Zelda, Diablo, and others, but frankly, it falls flat. All of the “humor” in the game is basically the game pointing and saying “isn’t this dumb?” It is basically explaining the joke, except there is no joke, just a reference to an older game which isn’t very funny.The game seems to suggest that you’re going to gradually move through various eras of games, but by about a third of the way into the game, you’re already up to 3D graphics, and it doesn’t really go beyond that. The game feels almost as if it has to rush through to unlock all the earlier stuff and then get to 3D for some reason, even though, quite frankly, the 3D gameplay isn’t very good (but then, neither is the 2D gameplay).Ultimately, the game is meant to be funny, but isn’t, and is meant to be fun, and also isn’t. The gameplay is as tedious as any old, poorly designed game with very little content; the JRPG overworld encounters happen every five steps or so and are pointless and tedious, while the dungeon Zelda-type movement is very basic, containing very little variety of monsters, none of which are particularly interesting to fight. The game contains three bosses, two of which are pretty boring; one of them is basically “stand there and hit it until it dies”, and another is a standard “dodge the charge and hit them” boss. Only the final boss shows any signs of real gameplay, and even there, it was kind of tepid.There’s just nothing here for anyone. If you’re looking for humor, the game isn’t funny; if you’re looking for a game which is fun to play, this isn’t. It doesn’t even feel original, as literally everything in it is referential, meaning any “originality” it might have from the whole idea of evolving into the modern day of gameplay is basically dead on arrival, buried under a pile of old video game references.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2013
												It's a really great concept. It's awesome to start the game in black and white and slowly unlock all the upgrades that came and went in RPGs. For the most part, it also has a great sense of humor. You'll LOL as you see it implement loading screens when it goes 3D and enjoy the many references to classics like Final Fantasy, Zelda and Dragon Quest. The Zelda segments, however, drag on WAY to long, if you ask me. With very few puzzles or deep mechanics, this game feels a good hour or two too long. Most dungeons are simply a walk and press attack romp and the turn based battles require no strategy at all. I'd wait till this puppy was on sale if I were you, but if you enjoyed the 8-bit and 16-bit RPG era as much as I did, you'll be glad you played this.PROS:Awesome ConceptNostalgia OverloadCons:Too Much FillerZero Replay Value

												When i first saw a picture of Evoland in Steam Store i was immediatly closing it cause it shows an 8bit green-grey, C64 style. Nothing against C64, i still have one, but i wont see that in 2013.Then i saw a little review accidently where i saw 3D grahics in it. My interest was awakened.Evoland is a time-travel between the grapic engines from C64 style to today. But the biggest reference of it is Final Fantasy VII.As mentioned you start with 8bit graphic and have to learn how to walk left and right, some minutes later you will unlock sounds and shortly thereafter COLOR!!! Well, the time from C64 to your first 3D effect is not very long, your first 3D HD graphics will come after 1 hour already.The whole game took me only ~4 hours. It was good invested 4 hours for me, for the price we could fight. 10€ (Sep2013) is ok but 5€ would be more fair for that playlength.The story is kinda funny, not only cause of that much references. 7/10

number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11
												This game is very indicative of the landscape of terrible gaming today. No matter whether you look at indie studios or big AAA companies, there is no such thing as a complete game anymore. They are just tiny gimmicks attempting to make a brief artistic statement on some unimportant aspect of life. You spend an hour playing through a glorified tutorial before finding out that the entire game is a tutorial. All of the things that you want to do as a player are blocked off, either because you haven't earned the right to play that part of the game yet, or they decided for you that freedom is stupid and you should feel bad for expecting to have fun. Exploration should not be punished, dissapointing, or a massive chore. But that's basically this entire game in a nut shell. You're always chasing the start of the game, and never get anything short of a sick joke making fun of actual game play.And to be honest, I'd have kept this entire opinion to myself if this game didn't offer itself up as such a wonderful treat for your steam controller. Guess what. It's broken. You have to use weird work arounds to get the steam controller to work, and even when it works once, there is no gaurantee that it won't break again between turning it off and on again.If you're up for wasting time, this one is the one for you. But don't expect to have fun or get your controller to work.

Posted: June 14, 2014
												I actually really like Evoland.It's not a perfect game, and it's not for everyone.What I like most about this game is that it parodies old RPGs and adventure games such as Zelda and FF6/7. Evoland does what I like best. It's not afraid to be itself. It makes fun of classics like FF7, and isn't afraid to do so, while also showing apreciation to it.The gameplay is basically zelda and FF combined, but simplified. The only real shortcomings of this game are the fact that it only lasts about 3-5 hours (about 10 for 100%), and that it has low replay value.Overally, I really like Evoland, and for its very cheap price of 10 dollars, it's worth a buy.

Posted: November 17, 2015
												Simple, but still fun.The game itself plays like five different games all merged together under one roof.  And honestly, each of those "games" by itself would be lacking.  Each section is simple, or even watered-down from you would get from such a title normally.  Overall, the gameplay is always shallow.  But instead of giving deep gameplay, it gives you a lot of gameplay variety.It never feels like it is trying to be challenging.  You can walk through the game without much fluster, and it won't be very demanding on your time.But the only reason these factors really seem to be present is because the game pulls in so many references and ideas from games that are demanding to our time or to our thinking.  It looks, sounds, and plays superficially just like a number of games that have deep and engaging gameplay, so if you are one of the long-time fans this game was made for, it isn't hard to notice that this game doesn't match the same depth and complexity of the games it reminds us of.But just when you reach the point where you can see that it isn't offering much, the game changes into something new and it feels like you're playing a whole new game.  It never stays on anything for too long, so it's always got something fresh to offer you.It's not revolutionary, it's not going to replace the games we grew up with.  It's just a simple homage.Even so, it still is fun.  It never makes a blunder where it reaches beyond itself.  It never even gets stale or boring.In the end, it's not great, but not bad.

Posted: October 31, 2015
												Jumping into Evoland I was expecting an experience very similar to 3D Dot Game Heroes, in the sense that we'd get a nice mirroring of many of our favourite nostalgic action/adventure/RPG's in a love letter to the aesthetic, gameplay and difficulty. However, going into this game I also didn't take into account that this was a mobile port so it managed to deliver about half those hopes at least.The gameplay for this game may start off (and arguably continue to be) clunky however it's extremely clever how not only the tutorial but the actual gameplay mechanics unfold. As you progress through the evolution of these genres instead of collecting weapons, armour, or loot, you collect visual elements and gameplay mechanics to progress through the decades.They do also have a cute story to accompany these elements, although not very prominent its a simple enough formula to just drop in reference after reference from all sorts of franchises from our childhoods such as (but not solely) Zelda, Final Fantasy, Pokemon, etc.I only really have two complaints with the game. It's simply too short, and there's so many other games that they could've paid tribute to especially in other genres that would've complimented the progression they created. Some may say that's asking for too much from a mobile port though, I wouldn't entirely disagree but only because the state of the mobile game industry is so abysmal right now.However with the sequel that was recently released it seems like they've fixed both of those complaints, however I'll have to get back to you on how I liked once I make it through the metric tonnes of games coming out lately.Overall though if you've played anything with weapons, armor or magic in between the 2 and 64 bit eras, you will want to see this game through to the end.

Posted: October 31, 2015
												This game is great fun. If you are a long time fan of old-school Final Fantasy or Legend of Zelda, this game will be a blast from the past. It also serves as a good introduction to what the action-adventure, action RPG, and JRPG genres were like in bygone days.Evoland is paced very well. Whenever a person lacking in patience would get tired of one mode of play, the game evolves and presents the player with something new to play with. Even completing all the side quests can be done with only a modicum of extra effort. I would reccommend this game to anyone and everyone.

Music.  Fighting. If you're in a soured mood and want to escape for a couple hours, give it a shot.  I put off playing this game for far too long, and when I finally got around to it I wondered why I hadn't touched it sooner.  I haven't touched a controller in months, but I immediately plugged one in upon discovering what a gem this game really is.My only complaint is that it was far too short... I want more.

I just need two or three cards and to play the champion card game, beat the noria boss without being hit, and collect 50k gold. Time to farm, lol. Posted: October 19, 2013
												Nostalgia goggles still firmly in place, I can't help but rave about this game. There are so many terrific homages to the games I grew up with and loved. Nods to The Legend of Zelda and Secret of Mana gave me the most warm and fuzzy feelings. Plenty of Final Fantasy VII references made me say, "Ah, yes." But more than references to games, Evoland references the very culture of gaming that I was raised in. The evolution of graphics and other technological advancements is presented in such a compelling way, I'd recommend this game for classes on pop culture or video game history.Taking the nostalgia goggles off, I find this game tight, well paced and well designed. Nothing seems to be filler and evolutions happen at a rapid pace so as to keep things interesting. The tongue-in-cheek storyline unfolds neatly and with no annoying spelling or grammar mistakes. New play styles are compelling, as well.While I appreciate the brevity of the game, some may not. It's not a terribly long story though I found there to be some replay value after completion. Players expecting a full RPG that will keep them going for a whole season will not find what they are looking for here. As for me, it took an evening and a morning to clear the story and I commend the designers for not fattening the game. It feels like the right length to make the most of the gimmick without making it feel annoying.I highly recommend this game.

Posted: January 4, 2014
												If you are an old school gamer who grew up on Zelda and Final Fantasy you will enjoy this game.  It is a playable version of a walk through gaming history.  It is such a unique and creative game while being a museum to the progression of gaming.  This is one of the most pleasantly surprising game I have bought in a long time.  Just Epic!  Highly recommend.

Posted: January 4, 2014
												Not a bad little game. Lasted me about 3-4 hours. I'd read some complaints about the mechanics but as long as you go in expecting a tribute to old school RPGs rather than a full-fledged game, it works great. It does turn into a fairly normal game once you get 3D, though, which is about 1/4 of the way in.My only real complaint is the random encounters on the overworld. It's one of those games where you can't take 3 steps without entering battle. There's also a cave with random encounters which makes exploring an absolute nightmare. This is only a small part of the game, though. As you probably know, the game "evolves" as you play and you use different battle systems and gameplay styles as you go so you don't have to deal with random encounters throughout the game, thankfully. Also, the battles are fast with enemies only taking 1-2 hits, usually.On sale, I'd definately recommend this game if you enjoyed such classics as The Legend of Zelda, Final Fantasy and Diablo. Full price is a stretch, though. I've played games way longer and more polished for $10.
