Posted: December 28, 2013
												This game was really cool.  It started out where gaining chests would *evolve* gameplay such as improving graphics or fidelity mirroring the development of games within the last few decades but I wouldn't call this game a gimmick.  It had very fun puzzle mechanics later on in the game where you would travel between the 8-bit world and the fully developed 3D world in order to progress and it made gameplay very interesting.  The storyline is more of a tool than an actual story since gameplay and the story closely mirror FF7/Zelda but it is humorous at times.  Gameplay was pretty cool in that it featured all sorts of gameplay including a very sillly Diablo level featuring tons of gear for example a ring of item finding which had a description of "helps you find an actually useful item".  The bad parts I would say are the RPG gameplay sections which I feel don't develop enough, and the very short length of the game.Overall, it was a very fun game and I would buy it if it went on sale again if I were you.  You can really tell the developer put a lot of love into the game.

Posted: December 29, 2013
												I really wish I would have read the reviews before buying this game. Even on flash sale, I'm not sure it was worth the money, not even as an interesting experience, because quite frankly, it just wasn't.The idea is interesting enough, and you get the impression that it's going to be a unique game that gradually introduces you into new elements of gameplay as you progress. What it actually is, is a game that has you wandering around with no clear direction until you find some hidden (some not) treasure chest with an "upgrade" in it. Within the first hour, you're already in the 3D world, and you don't even have time to feel nostalgic before it's taken away from you. The pacing was just plain bad, and I feel like maybe if they had worked a bit more to make a longer game, it could have been more of a success.I read a review that said they use humor as a crutch, and I'm going to go ahead and second that. It really isn't that funny though, and it feels as if they tried way too hard to make a game that would appeal to players of old-school RPGs, without actually delivering anything that made them good.Overall, I feel like a lot of work was put into the game, but it just wasn't executed well. The graphics aren't bad, and they had to make several different sprites for everything, not to mention the 3D models, and the music is all very good. I acknowledge and appreciate that work, but I still can't recommend this game in good conscience. I'd give it maybe a 5/10.

Posted: December 29, 2013
												The conceit is that you play through the history of RPG/Adventure games from the 80's until now all of which are built upon the world of Evolandia.  As you open chests, you unlock either collectibles or new game mechanics/visuals progressing through the era.At first I wasn't sure if it was satire or pastiche as the game didn't really have much to say about what it was putting before you.  There are a few in-jokes about RPG and Adventure characters, as well as a few familiar tropes in what is generally the barest bones of stories, and with the pace at which you discover new things early on the game can be amusing.  But at a certain point about halfway through the play time the game kind of just gives up and throws random game mechanics at you, taken from other games in the genres it references to be sure, but ultimately just kind of attached briefly and then discarded.My final conclusion about the satire/pastiche debate is that the game wants to be satire, mocking the genres it sets up, but it ends up being too fond of them and reliant upon them to actually critique them and instead just becomes a straight-up pastiche.  And that, unfortunately, is the tragedy of Evoland and why it falls flat on its face.  Rather than criticizing and attacking the failures of the RPG genre of the past, it reminds you of BETTER gameplay in some interesting one-off segments and then immediately buries you under everything you ever hated about RPGs.Random encounters?  Check.  Too many random encounters?  Check.  The inability to run from random encounters without getting your face smashed in?  Check.  Repetitive enemies?  Check.  The inability to automate these boring random encounters and go get a sandwich?  Check.  Pity, since Breath of Fire figured out automated fights back in the early 90's.But the game takes one extra step and gives you an inventory that is totally for show.  You can't equip weapons (fair enough, it's a short game), but you also can't use healing items or abilities between fights.  Which means if you just BARELY survive a random encounter, you better hope you get to a save point before your next one because otherwise it's right back to town.If it weren't for the fact that the game has you spending 50% of the time wandering the overworld map getting attacked every 4-5 steps, it could be forgiven for the utter, mind-numbing tedium you find yourself chained to.  Late in the game there's a decent modern-day RPG fight and the final boss actually has a bit of cleverness to him, but at this point if you didn't love everything about RPGs before you will probably hate the entire genre once and for all.I bought it for 2.50 and don't feel like my money was completely wasted.  But at a price point any higher than that, stay the heck away.

Posted: May 10, 2014
												What starts out as a celebration of the RPG quickly becomes a boring and bland romp through a game that's part Zelda and part Final Fantasy. The progression of visual and gameplay styles in the beginning is well-done, and one would be quick to compare it to DLC Quest. However, DLC Quest actually has tolerable writing, and it knows the difference between referencing something and outright imitating it. Evoland is packed with references to the point of overkill. Your character is named "Clink" and your accomplice is named "Caerith." She dies akin to Aerith in FF7.  You fight turtles, goombas, pirahna plants, octoroks, bats, and a boss named "Kefka's Ghost". Haha. Get it!?!?!?!?By the time you unlock 3D, the game's action comes to an abrupt plateau as you trudge through poorly-designed Zelda-inspired levels and grind through stale Final Fantasy-inspired fights. This game has absolutely no personality. The moment a story was added, the game became much more bland. I cared about nothing in the story, and I didn't get a single smile or chuckle out of the game. This game "references" the gameplay styles of Diablo, FInal Fantasy, Zelda, and Dragon Warrior, but it does them so half-baked that it stoops beyond boring, with some sections being ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly easy (Diablo-style) and some being mind-numblingly difficult (Zelda-style). Aside from that, there are a lot of glitches, such as maps being hard to navigate in 3D, being able to peer into the end of a map, extensive tile cracks, and the inability to use a controller DESPITE stating the game has controller support.So, all in all, Evoland is a game with good intentions, but it's completely devoid of imagination and thinks that outright copying other game styles passes as a reference. Each and every single thing about this game is half-baked, and it is by no means worth your money.Also, your airship looks like a dong.

												Boy I wish I'd read the reviews.  At first, I thought, "Oh awesome, a game that's going to involve features from my favorite RPGs!  It'll have grid based tactics and job systems and all that!"  Stop yourself there.  This is not a game, it is an FFVII fanfiction with Link inspiriations and a little bit of Diablo (probably when people got sick of hearing the publishers go on and on about FFVII).  Clink and Kaeris are not clever names.  About the time you get the Heroes sword, the feeling in my gut that this was about to turn into a bad FFVII remake was right on.Where was Final Fantasy Tactics?  Are you saying that isn't an RPG?Where was Tactics Ogre?  Are you saying that isn't an RPG?Where are the billions of other games with unique concepts?  Are those not RPGs?If you're going to describe the game as "Evoland is a journey through the history of action/adventure gaming, allowing you to unlock new technologies, gameplay systems and graphic upgrades as you progress through the game", make ♥♥♥♥ing sure you actually go through the history, not just "oh hey here's FFVII there that's what everyone wants anyway right?"  FFVII left a distinct mark on the industry, sure.  Look at me, I've got a Zack Fair profile picture and I think this is dumb.This is not a parody.  This is not a tribute.  This is the developers getting down on their knees and giving a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to a franchise that doesn't need one.Spend your 2.50 on getting a new case for FFVII or something, then play through the first Five hours of that and you've basically got the same game.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												A cute game that has something to say about the evolution of the console RPG, although it's clearly following Japanese tropes and styles; Diablo seems to be the only western-styled game to make an appearance. Simple, short, fun.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												2.5/5. The game wants really badly to be both a homage and spoof of classic games. If you've played DLC Quest, this is very similar in a lot of ways (you even start out without the ability to move left). However, Evoland doesn't have the same satire quality that DLC Quest did. Ultimately, most of the unlocks feel like the game is going "through the motions," and so the iterations through different art and playstyles weren't as satisfying as I'd hoped. The game itself feels pretty generic - like a crossover Zelda/FF7 clone without the charm. (On that note, the references to other video games are very heavy handed yet feel tacked on. Like characters frequently have one letter difference from what they are from.) I had an okay time playing it, but I wouldn't recommend getting this unless it was on sale.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												Evoland is a game about games. It's not a good game on it's own merit, but taking it for what it is, (being a game that is meant to take you through the Action/Adventure/RPG genres) it delivers a sense of nostalgia that can only be appreciated if you have played any of the games it constantly references or jokes about.The game borrows almost every aspect of itself from successful RPG's of the past and incorporates them into this journey through the evolution of games. Although the overall idea of the game is good, the delivery of things is a little underwhelming and it leaves the game with a sense of emptiness about it. Puzzles are simple, enemies are lifeless, areas are bland and empty, and collectibles require almost no work to get. Yes, Evoland certainly does take you through the Action/Adventure/RPG genre, but don't expect it to compete with the games it borrows from. Evoland is NOT a good RPG, but it IS a good experience. If you like RPG's, you'll like Evoland.If you're looking for an engrossing, original game, Evoland is not for you.All in all, I enjoyed it, but it's not a game I'll ever revisit or feel the need to play again.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												This game is less of an homage to several adventure games and RPGs from the past and more a shoehorning of A Link to the Past into Final Fantasy VII with a few character names barely obscured.  Speaking of shoehorning, the plot goes from boilerplate JRPG to essentially ripping off the most major scenes from FFVII without context or emotion in the last hour.That said, it does add some of its own character through the "evolution" of the graphics, sound and gameplay; it's a naturally flowing romp through all your favorite visuals in the first half with a rather pleasing visceral effect on someone that grew up at the same time.Unfortunately, the second half is almost entirely everything about FFVII battles that were tedious; constant, irritating, overly showy, slow turn-based battles with literally the same 4 or 5 enemies for all but two short sections.Pros: - Smooth gameplay - Amusing "upgrade" system for the graphics, sound, UI, and character gameplay - High on nostalgia if you're into thatCons: - Far, far too short (6 hours for me) - Gameplay padded by irritating, repetitive battles with the same enemies (fewer than 20 in game) - Not at all challenging, other than collection side questsVerdict:I don't feel cheated at the $2.50 price point I paid during a Steam sale.  I would have at the $10 regular price.  If you want a short trip down memory lane, you could do worse than Evoland; just wait until it goes on sale.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												Evoland is a video game that combines different aspects of RPGs and adventure games (namely Legend of Zelda and Final Fantasy) while "evolving" the game itself as you progress. This unique system not only provides an entertaining way to improve your experience, but it can evoke some nostalgia with gamers who played games on the SNES and PS1. For example, one improvement you can "unlock" is a town view that is reminiscent of Final Fantasy VII's style. I got this game for my birthday and I absolutely love it. However, this game is too short for it's own good. While it is extremely fun to play, once you beat it you feel like the the game was rushed in the end. Nevertheless, I would recommend this game to anyone looking to try something new or is a fan of final fantasy/legend of zelda.

Posted: April 30, 2014
												It's tough to recommend this game.  I know lots of people do not like games with a linear story.  This is a game that is very linear.  For someone like myself, I like to play a linear game once in a while.  I find the games with a hundred different side quests and campaigns to be daunting.  Also, I don't need to spend a 100+ hours of my life playing a game.  If I want something more streamlined, this is a game I would grab.  If you want something more streamlined, then grab this.  It's simple.  It's fun.  That's about all there is to it.  The story is by no means deep and intricate.  The gameplay could use some work (even simple enemies are a pain in the butt to defeat.  Then again, maybe that's because I've been playing this game on the keyboard when it should be played using a controller).  The puzzles are not too challenging.  The references to other games are not subtle in the least, yet it is kind of fun when you catch them.  This is definitely for someone who is not looking for something too challenging, too long, or too complex.  This game is made for the gamers who remember playing FFVII, Link's Awakening, and other classic adventure games from the 90's.  With that I say, try it out.  If you're skeptical, wait 'til it goes on sale and then download it.

Posted: July 7, 2014
												I don't recommend this, but only moderately. It has plenty of positives, but doesn't really offer much to the average gamer, even to the average RPG player. You would probably be better served just playing the games it copies (I say "copies" since I don't know how else to describe it, but I certainly don't mean the term negatively): The Legend of Zelda and Final Fantasy, especially. If you've played those (and Evoland mostly assumes you have), just play similar games that take themselves a little more seriously.Of course, Evoland is not a huge time sink: the whole thing will take 3 to 6 hours, depending on whether you speed through or try to find all the hidden items. It is shorter than it seems, though: the high random battle encounter rate and the tedious level design (which often requires you to go way around scenery obstacles for really no reason) drastically inflate how long the game takes. This is especially true if you want to do the optional goals, collecting cards and stars. The card game, which pretty much just copies Triple Triad from FF8, is pretty fun, but relatively easy and lacks replayability. The stars are pointless: they have no real purpose in the game, aren't explained, do nothing; the only real reason for them being there is to make another achievement and make the game seem like it lasts longer than it does.The MAJOR flaw with the game, though, is that it undermines its entire premise about halfway through. The "evo" part of Evoland is that you collect "upgrades" that let the game "evolve" from 8bit RPG mechanics and graphics to 3-D design and more recent mechanics. This was the most interesting part of the game, and makes the game valuable as a retrospective of the history of RPGS. About halfway through, though, you pretty much stop collecting any more upgrades. Indeed, the mimicking of other games just starts to happen randomly: the Diablo level is an example, where Diablo mechanics just show up and then go away after the level. Things stop to make much sense. Not that they do for the most part to begin with: often the sequence of upgrades makes no sense in terms of any real history of gaming "evolution." If the game would have stuck with the idea of evolution, making some of the earlier parts last longer (you move from 8bit to 3D very quickly, then get stuck in 3D for about 3 hours without the novelty of upgrades, making the story drag) and exploring the history of RPGs after FF8 (which is where it mostly stops), then it would probably be more interesting.Lastly, the story is just pointless. At first it's interesting as a parody of older RPGs, and then just becomes absurd. It stops working as a parody and gets cliche and doesn't even really seem to try. Since it's short, this may be worth playing if you have any interest in the history of RPGs or just like FF7. It is also a decent deal on sale. Overall, though, this is an interesting concept with woefully failed execution.

Posted: December 20, 2013
												While built upon an interesting premise, this game doesn't seem to use its full potential at all. It's absolutely linear and, once you've become accustomed to the fact that it upgrades its graphic style and changes some rules now and then, has no real "point" in playing. There is no engaging story, world or character and the gameplay itself isn't very motivating either. It's main selling proposition, traveling through the history of adventure / roleplay gaming, isn't really incorporated into its gameplay as well, except for a few designated spots - at least not within the 80 minutes I've played it. Nostalgia is all nice and good, but I didn't really feel entertained by the overall experience with Evoland.

Posted: November 17, 2015
												Simple, but still fun.The game itself plays like five different games all merged together under one roof.  And honestly, each of those "games" by itself would be lacking.  Each section is simple, or even watered-down from you would get from such a title normally.  Overall, the gameplay is always shallow.  But instead of giving deep gameplay, it gives you a lot of gameplay variety.It never feels like it is trying to be challenging.  You can walk through the game without much fluster, and it won't be very demanding on your time.But the only reason these factors really seem to be present is because the game pulls in so many references and ideas from games that are demanding to our time or to our thinking.  It looks, sounds, and plays superficially just like a number of games that have deep and engaging gameplay, so if you are one of the long-time fans this game was made for, it isn't hard to notice that this game doesn't match the same depth and complexity of the games it reminds us of.But just when you reach the point where you can see that it isn't offering much, the game changes into something new and it feels like you're playing a whole new game.  It never stays on anything for too long, so it's always got something fresh to offer you.It's not revolutionary, it's not going to replace the games we grew up with.  It's just a simple homage.Even so, it still is fun.  It never makes a blunder where it reaches beyond itself.  It never even gets stale or boring.In the end, it's not great, but not bad.

Posted: March 16, 2014
												When they say “short story,” they’re not joking. The game plays more like a story than a game. Granted, it is kinda cool in that the game actually does “evolve” as you play it, but it does so as a sort of history lesson more than anything. The problem here is that though I can still say it qualifies as a game, it does so only barely.  I’m not even saying it isn’t interesting, it’s just that it isn’t that fun. If you’re looking for a game that shows both retro and new age stuff with a definitive oldschool feel, well, there are plenty of those out there…and this isn’t it.Now, if you’re looking for something that operates somewhat like a game, but is more a history lesson about certain types of games, hey, go nuts.  This game really didn’t appeal to me. True, I haven’t beaten it so maybe it will get better. Maybe. I’m not putting money on it getting better, though. So far all that’s happened is Gameboy Zelda turned into GBA Zelda which then turned into not quite Final Fantasy 4. It’s an interesting concept, but again, remember that it is a…”short story.”

Posted: December 31, 2013
												This game is less of an homage to several adventure games and RPGs from the past and more a shoehorning of A Link to the Past into Final Fantasy VII with a few character names barely obscured.  Speaking of shoehorning, the plot goes from boilerplate JRPG to essentially ripping off the most major scenes from FFVII without context or emotion in the last hour.That said, it does add some of its own character through the "evolution" of the graphics, sound and gameplay; it's a naturally flowing romp through all your favorite visuals in the first half with a rather pleasing visceral effect on someone that grew up at the same time.Unfortunately, the second half is almost entirely everything about FFVII battles that were tedious; constant, irritating, overly showy, slow turn-based battles with literally the same 4 or 5 enemies for all but two short sections.Pros: - Smooth gameplay - Amusing "upgrade" system for the graphics, sound, UI, and character gameplay - High on nostalgia if you're into thatCons: - Far, far too short (6 hours for me) - Gameplay padded by irritating, repetitive battles with the same enemies (fewer than 20 in game) - Not at all challenging, other than collection side questsVerdict:I don't feel cheated at the $2.50 price point I paid during a Steam sale.  I would have at the $10 regular price.  If you want a short trip down memory lane, you could do worse than Evoland; just wait until it goes on sale.

												6/10  (With nostalgia 7.5/10)A love letter to console gaming with a focus on The Legend of Zelda & Final Fantasy, Evoland is a dry but fun trip down memory lane. Posted: April 12, 2016
												TL;DR Buy this when it's on sale. Good game, not really sure that it's worth $10.ReviewI don't know how anyone managed to get 5+ hours on this game unless they truely enjoyed it. Not saying it's a bad game--on the contrary, I really enjoyed it--but it's a very, VERY, short game. I beat it and got ALL Achievements within 2 hours and I felt like I spent a lot of time looking around. Note also, I did all of this without a guide.Pros and Cons+ Fun run through the land of Nostalgia+ Nice looking art+ Creative use of past and present art styles+ A handful of various historical battle systems that tie in together well+ You can name your character and his love interest... and her uncle...+ Airship+ Easter Egg Heaven- Very short- When you reach the "final" boss you will likely feel like you are at a "turning point boss" and start wondering why there isn't more.- For the RPG system, the encounter rate is set way too high, so if you take 2-3 steps, you will likely end up in a battle. This becomes frustrating mostly in dungeons.- Doesn't feel like a complete game.- Little to no plot. The storyline is nothing more than a mix of cliches from various games, most notably FF7. Don't play this game expecting an amazing storyline, it was created to further the nostalgia factors.Final VerdictI really enjoyed the short time I spent with this game, and if this one is anything to go by, I really hope it's just a taste of what the sequel will be like. They have something here, they just need to add a little more content and polish.

Posted: March 5, 2016
												I would have to say I both recommend and don't recommend this game. But the end of this review, I'll have decided which I would rather say overall, but I'll explain my reasonings:The concept of this game is great; a journey through the history of video games where you unlock the different things through finding them in chests. This is a very charming game and probably worth playing at least a little while just for the concept. If you are huge into RPGs and even other games, such as Minecraft, you will be able to enjoy the references and easter eggs throughout. (Yes, they make a reference to Minecraft once). However, these qualities can be overshadowed by the fact that the game feels like it's just stealing a bunch of games and mashing them together and the difficulty becomes increasingly frustrating. There is also one portion where you are able to choose between the male and female characters, and I had to restart my playthrough because playing as the girl made it much more difficult than when I went to play with the guy character. And in that same region, there are some minor graphical errors. The final boss battle is also pretty frustrating. It's simple, but it gives you absolutely no extra time to put in hits. The difficulty is frustrating at times, but as are a lot of games, so that attribute can be considered both a quality and an impedement. I did enjoy the minigame "Double Twin", I'm not sure how original it is, but it is fun.Overall, this is a pretty fun game. Enjoyable, although it does have its downsides. If you are bored and don't have anything else to play, it's an alright option.

Posted: April 19, 2016
												Evoland 1 is a fun action RPG, basically a mix of Final Fantasy and Zelda through the years. The gameplay is pretty solid as you evolve along with the story, but there is very little to distinguish this game as something that stands apart from its inspirations. The story is about as derivative as it could possibly be, and I don't think there's an original idea here except the actual 'evolving' as you play. It's fun to watch the graphics and gameplay style improve as you go, but some aspects never catch up. Could I get a run button or even a back button? Where is a list of the cards or stars I've collected? I was missing one of each by the end of the game, and there's no way I want to retread the entire map with an online guide to figure out which 2 chests in the whole game I missed. Also, this would be so much better with actual controller support. It feels even more disconnected from old school games when I'm using arrow keys and the space bar. Overall, it's still fun to play, but I wish it could stand on its own a bit better.

Posted: February 28, 2016
												4/5 ☆Such a brilliant little game with a very nice concept. You progress from from the 'Ye Olde' times of 8-bit black and white 2D all the way through to modern 3D graphics in a beautiful fantasy world. A nice blend of different RPG formats and battle systems from top down hackin and slashin and going HYA TOA TEEUH HAAA as is the native tongue of all young heroic elven children of the land of Zelda, to turn based combat in the overworld akin to Final Fantasy, and even a bit of 'lootget' slash 'n bash similar to the likes of Diablo or your preferred poison pick of the dungeon crawler RPG category. On top of that, you have the freedom to explore, seeking out secrets and collect all sorts of collectables - it even has a card based minigame based on the Triple Triad card game from Final Fantasy 8.My one complaint is that it's a bit on the short side. I was able to finish the game and 100% all the achievements in one sitting which was a little disapointing. I didn't really want it to end, and I could see potential for things to keep going, bigger and better. But if you're looking for a good few hours to burn and reminisce of the olden days of vidja gaming, I highly recommend you give it a go.

Posted: March 25
												evoland is a good concept, and fun to play. essentially, it's like an amalgam of various action/adventure games of the past, from final fantasy to zelda, and even a good mix of diablo thrown in. puzzles aren't too tough to figure out, and the portions where you have to switch between 2d and 3d to solve some of them, were really a good twist.the downside of it all though, is that (understandably) the gameplay mechanics had to be simplified for it to work in the various modes ... thus making the experience a lot more shallow in some ways. this puts it in a position where one might dispute the value you get for the price you pay. of course, i can also understand the effort required to build some of these maps, as they have to come in different 'forms' and 'versions' of itself.perhaps for the nostalgia, perhaps for the comedic tribute to some of the old games, but regardless, evoland does hold good potential to be something unique. in the meantime, i guess i'd still lean towards giving this a thumbs up, if not for anything, more for the potential it holds. perhaps we'll see it evolve further in evoland2 then.

												What Jarin said, except that as one who did not play the old console games it was fun to go through that progression. Posted: July 21, 2013
												Evoland is a must-play for any fan of the RPG genre. It will take you on a trip through memory lane, reliving all of your favourite games, from Final Fantasy to Zelda. You start off as an 8-bit game, and will constantly find treasure chests that will evolve the game's mechanics and the world around you. It will remind you of some of the great things about those games, but is not hesitant to point out their flaws too. Of course, Evoland is not without its own flaws, but this is a parody made out of love for the genre. The nostalgia, the tongue-in-cheek approach and the ever-changing world will make this a joy to play for RPG-fans, and will surely give them a warm feeling inside.

Posted: June 11, 2014
												Evoland is, at its core, a game about games, and the ability to enjoy the game is based heavily on a player's ability to chuckle or even laugh out loud at each reference the game makes.  It is an action RPG/RPG that switches up its mechanics to illustrate a point, a simple and barebones fight engine in whatever form it takes, and it often pokes lighthearted fun at everything that came before and is happening now.  It starts in the black and white(ish) graphics of the old Gameboy, and each treasure chest, instead of giving you equipment or items, gives you a new feature, a game instance (such as a forced battle), a slight quip, and encouragement to continue on and exploring the world.  Or a star or card, of which the game has many; they're both linked to achievements, and after obtaining them all, it sort of made me think about all the random collections games have you do for very little reward, and I realized these were also part of the game poking fun at games.And it's all in fun.  References to the Legend of Zelda, Final Fantasy, Crystalis, Diablo and even Mario games abound, without having to be direct one-to-one examples.  More often they are not-so-subtle amalgams of the elements of those games.  And the shifting playstyles and new “Additions” to the game overall feel . . . right.  They work very well together.  This game being simple does not mean it is inferior.  However, one might feel that the battle systems are sometimes too . . . easy.  Almost like an RPG where you've leveled to 99 or a Zelda game after getting all the hearts, there is not a lot of difficulty to be found here.  But that is just as well, to me, as the game's not really about the difficulty, but where we've been.For a fun, simple romp through an interactive history of game mechanics, I say you can't really go wrong.  My only real reservation is that I don't actually feel that the game is “worth” $10; I would suggest getting it on a sale for at least 50% off.But other than that, the game is fun, provided you don't take yourself (or it) to seriously.

Posted: April 5, 2013
												With just shy of 2 hours under my belt, I'm already enjoying the heck out of Evoland. The game starts with 8-bit retro-Gameboy-spinach-green graphics and allowing you to only walk right. That's it.  And from that point on it's up to you to evolve through gaming history in terms of features, sound, graphics, and gaming styles to make your way. The game makes me think, 'what will the next unlockable be?' as I explore and find chests that could hold the next upgrade, whether it be a new feature, an upgrade in graphics, or sound. Heck, a recent one allowed me to break jars finally with my sword. You'll also be taken through various RPG battle styles, keeping things a bit more fresh when on one moment you're battle 8/16-bit Zelda style, and next you're doing random encounters and battle menus like Final Fantasy. If you're a RPG fan, or a gaming fan in general, do yourself a favor and give Evoland a shot.

Posted: June 19, 2015
												Greetings, I just replayed this game and I must say that it is still an enjoyable experience.  In many ways this game feels more like a documentary of gaming history than a standalone game.  Regardless of that it is a lot of fun.Nostalgia:  This game pulls at the strings of not only the evolution of technology but also the evolution of RPGs.  The mechanics themselves may not be that original (or even at all, as I feel it is the intention) but they are done well and with precision.  This is one of few games that I won’t complain about precision of mechanics and controls as they are spot on.Old but New:  This game does an amazing job at presenting the various game designs of the games they tribute; the sound is solid and the graphics feel clean but within their genre.  I do wish there was more however as there is really only about 3-5 hours of play.A Story not told:  The story is more or less non-existent, the atmosphere is there and yes there is a story but you don’t really care and there isn’t much to follow; but to be honest, this isn’t an issue.  An amazingly deep story is not why you are here; you are here to relive your childhood or to at least appreciate the progression of RPGs.Overall, if you are a gamer you should get this game.  If you want to live through the history, get this game.  Really I feel this is a lesson in our history that every player should participate in, even if it is just done for learning and not for the gaming purpose.  Yes, you only get 5 hours about but it is short enough to hold your attention but long enough to demonstrate everything well.  Enjoy!

Posted: May 23, 2014
												This game wears out its welcome after the first fifteen minutes. It quickly jumps through the early eras of gaming, which was the only reason I bought the game, and then devolves into an insipid mishmash of poorly executed gameplay. To break it down, the game begins with a Zelda-stlye top down action game, which, while competently executed, lacks the aesthetic beauty, creativity, or excellent design which define excellent games like Link to the Past or Minish Cap. The visuals are uninspired, and the enemy design is limited to very few, extremely repetitive octorock clones and bats. There are one or two interesting boss fights, but it remains dull and uninteresting. After this you are hurled into a truly horrifically designed Final Fantasy clone. Lacking a mana system, it is utterly dull and a chore to grind through. Outdated principals like random encounters and a totally pointless item system makes this truly digusting. To make it worse, this takes up the majority of the games 5 or 6 hour lifespan, and the endgame is almost nothing but it. There are a few bright spots. Sort of clever Easter Eggs are hidden in a few spots, and the Diablo style level is both challenging and a scathing mockery of the goofy loot system in such games. Overall, however, the game is disappointing, uninspired, slapdash, and dull. There is no way in hell this thing is worth 10 dollars or your time. Heartily not recommended.

Posted: April 17, 2014
												I remember playing the Flash demo for this about a year or so ago and getting really excited for this. It seemed quirky, had a lot of the GOOD elements from the adventure games it was parodying and displaying, and the upgrade system was really cool. Someone already wrote a review saying it, but I'm saying it again just in case the message didn't get across: the first half is awesome. Although things like the left button and such are silly, it does a pretty decent job of taking you through the early days of video games step by step between the Adventure games like Zelda and the RPGs like Final Fantasy. However, this is cut short when you get to the part where you can finally jump into the third dimension. There's some awesome puzzles around this part where you have to go back and forth between dimensions, but any time you're on the overworld it becomes a slog of random encounters and you quickly see that along with the history of these games, the developer has left in some of the worst parts of them.It seems like to me that around the 3d stage of the game, the developer started to get lazy. The random encounters aren't balanced (or, if the point was to be just "annoying", the encounters aren't easy enough to shrug off since it will often pick a very unfair amount of enemies for your low level party that hasn't had a chance to buy healing items and the last save was FIFTEEN MINUTES AGO IN THE MIDDLE OF A DUNGEON ARRRGHHH) and it's at this point when the upgrades, which in the beginning are major graphical and audio and mechanics upgrades, start to just be "Textures" "HD Textures" "Lighting" "DYNAMIC Lighting". The last really cool area is to get the first part of an Amulet you need, but its followed up by the second part, which while being a very cool Diablo scenario, falls short by having it be a hack and slash fest with waves of enemies that are absolutely ridiculous- even by the standard of the game it's parodying. Maybe it's not really that hard, but the problem is that you're in a Diablo-esque combat setting with those clunky Zelda controls. And the boss is literally just hit and run, as compared to the first boss that actually had some strategy, and to add insult to injury you get items and fight a ton of stuff along the way that does NOTHING for you.When you get back into the overworld, all those monsters you fought didn't give you XP (just some gil) and the items you got were all joke items, one of them even telling you to just hit and run the boss. Not to mention, it's been probably a half hour to an hour, depending on how much you've died at this part, since the last time you saw a 2d location or gotten to do any of those sorts of puzzles.Its after this part shortly you get an airship and can travel freely around the world, and at this point I stopped. You can travel back to one of the first villages of the game and it just sort of... pops back into 2d mode. Even though it established a dimension travelling mechanic... all of a sudden it just pops you in. Maybe I have just too high expectations from the demo, but... this was just the pinnacle of laziness to me. Maybe this game can pass as a mini-history lesson about the games industry, but as anything else it falls flat on it's face and spits in the face of anyone who saw potential for this as an actual game.Last complaints: the game's buggy as hell. It has an option for a gamepad but won't actually detect it. It also never properly explains controls or let's you rebind stuff. There are a lot of times when you'll load up a save and not have some of the powerups you picked up beforehand. Like, I actually managed to walk past the random encounters chest because of a glitch, and I probably should have counted my blessings. And the UI leaves a LOT to be desired, especially in situations like the Diablo level where everything is just suddenly different (and then changes back to the original UI for certain areas when you return to them).Final verdict: I bought this game on sale, and it's barely worth that. I mostly wanted to help the developer because I remembered this seeming really cool, but I obviously should have read the reviews first. Hope this helps someone. Instead of buying a history lesson, just pick up one of those oldies and play it for yourself... or play one of the many other indie games that devote themselves to those mechanics and stick with it the whole way through to make an actual GAME.

Posted: March 29, 2014
												Evoland is a unique game is every way, sane for its gameplay. Now, this might sound like a strange way to describe the game, but allow me to elaborate further.Evoland is a game wherein you start with a basic, black and white, 8-bit adventure game where you can only move right. While, like other Adventure games, you must unlock items to progress, you must also progress by unlocking game features. From features as banal as breaking pots, to as important as having a health bar, many gameplay elements which are nowadays considering traditional and mandatory, must be discovered.And this is why you WILL enjoy Evoland if you have a taste for nostalgia. The game is a clear salute to classics like Final Fantasy, Legend of Zelda, Monster Quest, and even Diablo. If you like any of those games, you'll notice at least half a dozen references and nods made to those games throughout the game. However, these are Duke Nukem style of references - heavy handed and not sly in the slightest.It's an interesting premise, and seeing the game evolve from original Gameboy graphics to a 3D cartoony style fitting for any modern indie game is rewarding in its own merit. As long as you're unlocking new things, you'll be having a blast, and chuckling when the game offers sarcastic or tongue-in-cheek humor at the expense of tropes common of old-school games.While this is all well and good, the "combat" is dull as a doornail. As stated earlier, the game takes inspiration from LoZ, Final Fantasy, and Diablo. There are three different "combat" systems that activate in specific areas, all of which are a copy of other game's combat systems, without the same depth or complexity.The Final Fantasy combat system doesn't have nearly as many party members, spells, options, or items. It doesn't even have an MP system, so you can spam spells as much as you want, making the game dreadfully easy.The LoZ combat system offers a sword that can only be swung (no charing, spinning, or anything fancy), unlimited bombs (though only one can be shot at a time), and arrows. The Diablo combat system has NO active abilities, no level ups, no meaningful looting (obsesive looting is treated as a joke in these sections, instead of as a gameplay mechanic) and not even a mana bar.These "combat systems" also suffer from two more fatal flaws. For one, you don't get to choose what combat system you use. If an area is a Diablo combat area, you can't run through the area again with the Final Fantasy combat system. Secondly, the game is just too easy. I only died once in the entire game, and that's simply because I didn't figure out the solution to the final boss fight before he killed me.Speaking of the final boss -- if you need a good story, don't get involved. The game is a nostalgia trip, and it plays old games having bad and cliche stories as a joke. With all the negatives aside, I will say this. Evoland is a unique, and genuinely funny experience. While the game's combat is dull, seeing what gameplay element you will unlock next pushes you through until the very end. If you need a good nostalgia hit for the days of the SNES and Genesis, look no further.

Posted: April 9, 2014
												So, first a caveat to this game, especially considering the words of some of the negative reviews.This is less a game and more a celebration of the earliest days of RPGs. Honestly, for most people, I think you have to hit the right age (not much younger than mid 20s or so) to really get what Evoland is all about. RPGs have evolved a lot in the past 15 years or so, and Evoland doesn't really touch too much of that. (I'd love a bigger and higher funded sequal that did though.)To those of us who grew up playing JRPGs on the NES and SNES, who played the original Zeldas, who killed so much time with the first Diablo... This game boils all those concepts down into its one step at a time pace. It was really well done, the unlocking of various graphical, sound, and gameplay features. It brought back a lot of memories and also helped really bring into focus the build up these games have had over the years.I think if you're into game development, it is especially a magnificent experience. To show you how things were played with, how they were built upon a step at a time to the modern games of today.As for the game itself, it's not going to be everyone's cup of tea. I certainly suggest not paying more than five dollars for the game, as well done as it is. It's about 5 hours worth of play time (I myself bought it and beat it in a single sitting, complete with every single achievement). And if you don't like the way that JRPGs used to be, then you might want to hold off completely. Yes, there are random encounters, and yes, the encounter rate is a bit extreme. As well, the combat is super complex, and there isn't much challenge until late in the game. But that's not really the point. Nor is the quick, standard story.It's a very hard concept to define. It's not pure nostalgia. And it's not really about gimmicky concepts. It's sort of understanding that there were and are limitations to this style of gameplay, and yet one can love it all the same. We DID love it all the same. Sure, it's frustrating in some ways, but we put up with it. We learned how it worked and we did it.I'm rambling, so I'll get to the point. It's a sale game, for sure. But for all those who put hundreds of hours into the various RPGs we had as we were growing up, I heavily suggest it. It's a nice little aside for a few hours.

Posted: March 2, 2014
												This game is just about perfect in content and length for RPG fans in our mid-thirties (plus or minus).  Bits and pieces of all the games we've loved packed into about 6 hours of gameplay - because that's all the time we have anymore, isn't it?  Of course along with the bits we loved come some bits that were kind of obnoxious, and there are a few lighthearted jabs at them.  The only real problems I can see with this game is that the frequency of overworld random encounters borders on the frustratingly high and the evolution of the game slows down considerably the farther along you progress.  It would have been nice to have paced the earlier evolutions a bit more slowly and had a bit more variety to the turn-based RPG combat, but it's still quite fun as it is and not a bad buy if you catch it on sale.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												This game is less of an homage to several adventure games and RPGs from the past and more a shoehorning of A Link to the Past into Final Fantasy VII with a few character names barely obscured.  Speaking of shoehorning, the plot goes from boilerplate JRPG to essentially ripping off the most major scenes from FFVII without context or emotion in the last hour.That said, it does add some of its own character through the "evolution" of the graphics, sound and gameplay; it's a naturally flowing romp through all your favorite visuals in the first half with a rather pleasing visceral effect on someone that grew up at the same time.Unfortunately, the second half is almost entirely everything about FFVII battles that were tedious; constant, irritating, overly showy, slow turn-based battles with literally the same 4 or 5 enemies for all but two short sections.Pros: - Smooth gameplay - Amusing "upgrade" system for the graphics, sound, UI, and character gameplay - High on nostalgia if you're into thatCons: - Far, far too short (6 hours for me) - Gameplay padded by irritating, repetitive battles with the same enemies (fewer than 20 in game) - Not at all challenging, other than collection side questsVerdict:I don't feel cheated at the $2.50 price point I paid during a Steam sale.  I would have at the $10 regular price.  If you want a short trip down memory lane, you could do worse than Evoland; just wait until it goes on sale.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												Do you like RPGs?  Do you enjoy irony, wit and win?  Try Evoland.I'm not sure which wall Evoland breaks when the game has you unlock gaming elements but it makes for an outstanding experience.    Players start with Gameboy-like graphics and a serious lack of options.  Both can be remedied by bumping into chests that unlock things like 16-bit graphics (which improve!) and save points.  Some more recognizable RPG elements included are FF6, Diablo, Ocarina of Time as well as similar game mechanics.  I would like the game more if any mechanic you unlocked stayed available throughout.  One early dungeon can be frustrating due to the inability to use healing potions or companion characters even if both are unlocked.Thankfully the game does not include 16-character "save codes" ala Metroid or Goonies II.  Some RPG elements should stay buried.9/10 for creativity7/10 for inconsistent game mechanics

Posted: October 31, 2015
												Jumping into Evoland I was expecting an experience very similar to 3D Dot Game Heroes, in the sense that we'd get a nice mirroring of many of our favourite nostalgic action/adventure/RPG's in a love letter to the aesthetic, gameplay and difficulty. However, going into this game I also didn't take into account that this was a mobile port so it managed to deliver about half those hopes at least.The gameplay for this game may start off (and arguably continue to be) clunky however it's extremely clever how not only the tutorial but the actual gameplay mechanics unfold. As you progress through the evolution of these genres instead of collecting weapons, armour, or loot, you collect visual elements and gameplay mechanics to progress through the decades.They do also have a cute story to accompany these elements, although not very prominent its a simple enough formula to just drop in reference after reference from all sorts of franchises from our childhoods such as (but not solely) Zelda, Final Fantasy, Pokemon, etc.I only really have two complaints with the game. It's simply too short, and there's so many other games that they could've paid tribute to especially in other genres that would've complimented the progression they created. Some may say that's asking for too much from a mobile port though, I wouldn't entirely disagree but only because the state of the mobile game industry is so abysmal right now.However with the sequel that was recently released it seems like they've fixed both of those complaints, however I'll have to get back to you on how I liked once I make it through the metric tonnes of games coming out lately.Overall though if you've played anything with weapons, armor or magic in between the 2 and 64 bit eras, you will want to see this game through to the end.

Posted: November 17, 2015
												Simple, but still fun.The game itself plays like five different games all merged together under one roof.  And honestly, each of those "games" by itself would be lacking.  Each section is simple, or even watered-down from you would get from such a title normally.  Overall, the gameplay is always shallow.  But instead of giving deep gameplay, it gives you a lot of gameplay variety.It never feels like it is trying to be challenging.  You can walk through the game without much fluster, and it won't be very demanding on your time.But the only reason these factors really seem to be present is because the game pulls in so many references and ideas from games that are demanding to our time or to our thinking.  It looks, sounds, and plays superficially just like a number of games that have deep and engaging gameplay, so if you are one of the long-time fans this game was made for, it isn't hard to notice that this game doesn't match the same depth and complexity of the games it reminds us of.But just when you reach the point where you can see that it isn't offering much, the game changes into something new and it feels like you're playing a whole new game.  It never stays on anything for too long, so it's always got something fresh to offer you.It's not revolutionary, it's not going to replace the games we grew up with.  It's just a simple homage.Even so, it still is fun.  It never makes a blunder where it reaches beyond itself.  It never even gets stale or boring.In the end, it's not great, but not bad.

Posted: September 3, 2015
												Evoland follows a fantastic idea that a lot of players and developers had had but that is seldom actually implemented, a game where not only the player and their avatar advance through a virtual world but also the game and bespoken world develop as you go along. Mechanically I'd describe the development as roughly going from Mystic Quest on the Gameboy to Final Fantasy VII - there are developments in other directions as well.+ Good music+ Okay story+ Interesting and well implemented idea+ Mostly good controls0 Rather shortThere is not a lot to be said about Evoland. It features good music developing, together with graphics, through some generations of technology. The controls are good, except for some degradation at the end, when suddenly you need to turn before attacking in order to attack in the direction of a monster as opposed to the direction of your previous movement.It's nice, that I had to figure out how to beat the final boss.It seems the developers wanted to recreate some of the stronger and not exclusively positive impressions we collected over the years. That's how I rationalise artificial loading times and the piece of the game where you're basically required to grind for some time.I think, it's due to the Ludum Dare 48h Challenge that concepts are somewhat fast-changing and that the game is overall pretty short. Nevertheless, at least the Steam version of the game - I don't know the LD version - is well-implemented and provides some hours of fun (not counting the short grinding phase)I easily recommend Evoland, especially to players of the games close in style to those games mentioned above. I'm looking forward to playing the sequel and owe thanks to Ludum Dare for bringing about the creation of games like this one.

Posted: December 21, 2014
												Evoland takes a fantastic concept, the evolution of the action RPG, and plays it out with mixed results. The game begins in very simplistic 2D, but soon begins to play very similarly to the original top-down Legend of Zelda games (think Link's Awakening). After more time, the game progresses into full-blown 3D, more akin to PS1/PS2 Final Fantasy games, and even further onward to open exploration, like Diablo. There's all sorts of collectibles and monster encounters as you'd come to expect, and the package is hilarious and represents its source material very well.However, the game isn't without its faults. The transition to 2D to 3D is somewhat rough, and the game starts to lose a bit of polish there. Also, at all points in the game, hit detection can act oddly, leading to your character taking hits due to some wonky hitboxes, or in some cases, pushing your character through walls in a dungeon, leading you unable to continue without restarting. These problems are obviously very annoying, and make the experience worse overall.Would I recommend the game, given the balance of positives (nostalgic value, good design) and negatives (bad hit detection, suspect 3D game mode execution)? Yeah, but not at full price. The game is great for what it is, but it's short (the game takes 2-3 hours, maybe 4 if you are trying to collect everything), and the bugs can be very frustrating. Therefore, if you're interested in things like Zelda and Final Fantasy, be sure to give Evoland a look - if you can catch it for a large discount in a sale.

Posted: January 2, 2015
												Evoland is probably one of the coolest ideas for a game I've seen.  When I first looked into this game however I was hit with tons of poor reviews on it, so I was hesitant to buy it.  This year's humblebundle sale had it really cheap though so I jumped in.  Evoland takes RPGs from early to recent and rolls them all into 1  crazy game.  Whenever you open a chest you never know what is going to happen.  Final Fantasy, Zelda, Diablo etc. are all referenced in this game, and generally in very humorous ways.  However it is not all good.  Though fantastic the game is rather short.  It can be beaten in about 1-5 hours, and several of the "evolutions" of the game come at you all at once so you go from NES level up to Final Fantasy 7 level pretty quick.   Also the game is known for being buggy.  I got stuck in a bug that left the game unplayable, by setting the airship down right next a forest that could not be exited from that side.PROsFantastic ideaVariety of graphics and gameplay updates throughoutOften hilarious upgrade notes and itemsSolid gameplay mechanics and combatCONsShort gameCan be very buggyLacks any kind of deep plotVery few sidequestsSimple item, magic and combat system leave little room for strategies.Overall I think this game is very much worth a play through at the right price.  I am very much looking forward to Evoland 2 and hope for a longer, more in depth story, with no game breaking bugs.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												The game assigns you puzzles assuming you've played both the Final Fantasy and Zelda series, but if, like me, you never liked Zelda, you will quickly tire of the extended timing- and reflex-based battles.  Bought this in the Summer 2015 sale and I'm not really sure I got my money's worth - less than 2 hours in, I'm stuck on a boss battle that I have no idea how to defeat, and no interest in running multiple times to figure out.Save points are too far between - I understand that the idea is to progress through the history of console RPGs, but mimicing one of the most panned and unnecessary characteristics seems rather sadistic on the part of the developer.  It's just poor design to stump you on a boss battle and then make you jump through hoops just to get back to that battle.  That exact combination is why I'm moving on to another game, and the extent of my remaining use of this game will be to run it at the title screen while I watch TV to collect the cards (if and only if I am ineligible for a refund).

Posted: June 20, 2015
												To make a long story short, Evoland is a hands-down thumbs-up fingers-crossed interactive documentary about the early history of the action adventure game genre. The game intentionally starts out lame and progressively improves in gameplay and graphics the further you press on, giving players a history of how action adventure started from side-scrollers to top-down hack-and-slash to turn-based action to puzzler to tactical turn-based combat to horde hack-and-slash.Veteran gamers might not get much more than a nostalgia-induced parody, but this is a good introduction for kids to the world of retro action adventure games.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												Feeling nostalgic? This new game feels like an old friend as it walks through different stages of game technology and progresses as you move through the story. Graphically, some areas maintain a SNES-like appearance, while others move into textured, but cartoonish 3D. The overall story is simple, though it resembles a Legend of Zelda game, to which Evoland pays homage. It's doesn't take long to push through the entire game, and even though it has some tricky sections, it's not frustratingly difficult. Achievements are achievable, and some might have you scratching your head without the aid of a walkthrough. There are multiple types of battles (turn-based and real time.) Boss battles are a mix of skill and strategy, and the game plays easily on a laptop keyboard. If you're looking for a fun, but new walk through memory lane, Evoland is woth a download.

Posted: August 18, 2015
												Evoland is an interesting game, not for its look, but for its gameplay.Much like the game "Life of Pixel", this game centers around evolving through different eras of video games. Unlike "Life of Pixel", this game is more Legend of Zelda/Final Fantasy/WoW in its RPG approach of gameplay (while LoP focuses on the aesthetic of specific video game consoles from the 70s-90s using platforming mechanics). Both games are great for nostalgia factor alone.If there are any nitpicks, I was a little disappointed in how sparse the story felt, but I didn't let that keep me from enjoying the exploring. I didn't care about the villain, but I did care about the environment and the exploration.When the game was first released, it was a little buggy, and some of the bosses' hitboxes didn't trigger, which made beating the game frustrating, but I am pretty sure that was resolved since I 100% this game a few months after. The act of collecting cards and playing a variation of FFVIII's Triple Triad card game is enough to get this. If not, then appreciate all the nods to your favorite retro games of yesteryear. No matter how you look at it, Evoland is a fun game. Give it a go, then brace yourselves for Evoland II, because it looks like everything the first game is, but better.

Posted: June 22, 2014
Extremely Exciting Evolutionary Expedition! Enjoy Evoland!Evoland is by far one of the most unique games I've ever had the pleasure to play. It takes heavy inspiration from the Zelda and Final Fantasy series of games, among others, but introduces a very creative twist. As you progress through your awesome adventure, you frequently find charitable chests that ultimately upgrade the grand game itself with new technologies and gameplay mechanics. You start out in a limited monochrome environment, only able to move to the right, and eventually move to full-blown 3D. Don't think you'll stay there the entire time though!As if that wasn't enough, the game is positively packed with plenty pretty pleasing parodies that promise to put prospective players in a state of near nonstop nostalgic bliss, especially when combined with the upgrades. Those more aware of the evolotuion of video games will be totally tickled at all the really retro references revealed~One of the most impressive aspects of this game is its origins as the August 2012 Ludum Dare winner. For those unaware, the Ludum Dare competition is one that provides particularly passionate participating programmers the perplexing puzzle of promptly producing a potential playable prototype- er, game, in 48 hours. There are no prizes, but as anyone can plainly see, they can inspire impressive innovations like this~

												Definitely worth picking up. Touches back to Zelda style hack and slash, to Final Fantasy turn base, and then even a bit of Diablo's style of hack and slash (1 cave). Posted: July 6, 2015
												A remarkable exploration of the development of game mechanics & visual styles through gaming history. Evoland starts with little more than could be expected of a Classic 8bit Role Playing / Adventure Game later exploring more complex elements of design with comfortable development from Zelda-Style hack top-down combat to turn based combat much in the style of JRPG's of the Playstation 1 era, and later developing into a Diablo-esque hack 'n' slash.The narrative is mostly superfluous so if you're in search of a gripping story you're out of luck. What the game lacks in depth it more than makes up for in the unique charecter of the gameplay in the use of graphical and gameplay advances as player rewards.Some may find game length to be an issue and having completed it in under 5 hours I'd be inclined to feel the same, with only 5 hours of content I was left wanting more, the itteration of mechanics was rewarding enough to foster a continuation of the gaming session and as a result I completed it in only two sessions. One thing I must mention, and consiquentally penalise the final score for, is the abrubt ending so soon after a new transport mechanic is introduced, my personal reccomendation would have been to use development time expeded on the CCG minigame to expand the scope to include at a minimum an additional populated town with it's associated side-quests for an addtional hour of content.7.5/10

Posted: July 6, 2015
												A remarkable exploration of the development of game mechanics & visual styles through gaming history. Evoland starts with little more than could be expected of a Classic 8bit Role Playing / Adventure Game later exploring more complex elements of design with comfortable development from Zelda-Style hack top-down combat to turn based combat much in the style of JRPG's of the Playstation 1 era, and later developing into a Diablo-esque hack 'n' slash.The narrative is mostly superfluous so if you're in search of a gripping story you're out of luck. What the game lacks in depth it more than makes up for in the unique charecter of the gameplay in the use of graphical and gameplay advances as player rewards.Some may find game length to be an issue and having completed it in under 5 hours I'd be inclined to feel the same, with only 5 hours of content I was left wanting more, the itteration of mechanics was rewarding enough to foster a continuation of the gaming session and as a result I completed it in only two sessions. One thing I must mention, and consiquentally penalise the final score for, is the abrubt ending so soon after a new transport mechanic is introduced, my personal reccomendation would have been to use development time expeded on the CCG minigame to expand the scope to include at a minimum an additional populated town with it's associated side-quests for an addtional hour of content.7.5/10

Posted: July 14, 2015
												It's DLC Quest done much more correctly. It's somewhat impressive that they managed to fit these various different styles and graphical modes into a 106 MB game, but it's all rather skin deep. When you try to find depth in anything that isn't the Zelda sections, you come up empty handed. The premise is amazing, but it was poorly executed and lackluster. The action sections are nothing to write home about, it's Legend of Zelda in 2D and 3D, save for the Diablo ruins, which while fun and allows you to actually use your second character, is sadly locked to that one location. If the final boss were allowed to be done in that style, I would have been much happier... more so if I could have turn based him. That is the real deal breaker for me: the turn based combat turned out to be incredibly shallow, and ultimately, pointless. There is exactly one boss which is dispatched via turn based, after that, everything else is done in action RPG sections. Glis is only ever useful in buying the tiny handful of items needed for achievements, your level in turn based does not give you more hearts or allow you to better tank damage in the action sections. Worse, you have no access to your ability to heal (either by the potions you never use in turn base or the spell) or second character in the action sections, rendering them pointless for the majority of the game.Yes, you can get an extra heart for the action sections via the turn based battles, but that's far too little to justify its existence, especially since all it really does is make the final boss easier.I have to, almost grudgingly, give Evoland a negative vote. I hope the lessons learned here will allow for the second game to offer more substance in its play modes.

Posted: February 4, 2015
												So I just beaten Evoland today. It was okay. That's it. I would write a review, but there is no option for 'Meh...'. Personally where I think this game could improve is if it had more of an identity. Almost anything interesting about this game is taken directly out of another. Paying homage to a game is fine, but I think Evoland takes it a bit too far. Why make something original when you can just say 'Hey! Remember this thing guys!'. If they made their own story and characters to it, I would adore it, because finding chests to literally upgrade the entire game in little ways is one of the most unique things I've ever seen in an rpg. It made me excited to see what the next chest would hold (unless it was just a star of course). It's not great, but also not terrible. A bit more of a challenge would be nice, I bought a couple Phoenix Downs but only used them during a fight where, I didn't know this at the time, I was actually supposed to lose.Personally I wouldn't recommend this just for the sake that there are better games available for the same price.

Posted: September 15, 2015
												Buy this game if: you want a trip down nostalgia-lane.  This game brought back a lot of good gaming memories for me, from 8-bit side scrollers (a la the original Legend of Zelda) to more recent RPG romps like Final Fantasy 8,  Skip this game if: you want an experience that will last longer than 10 hours (I completed 97% of the game in about 8 hours with minimal usage of a guide), if you can't get the game on sale, if you are looking for a particularly hard game (the only thing I had to retry more than once was the final battle) or if you can't abide by the fact that the game is, "openly inspired," by (i.e. rips off) other titles, such as the card battling mechanic which Evoland clearly stole from Final Fantasy 8 or the user interface it stole from 2D Legend of Zelda.  ---Extended thoughts:Though switching from 16-bit to 3D graphics was novel, it was underutilized in the game.  Moreover, though the game tried to parody many popular franchises (e.g. trash items in Diablo or forced encounters in most RPGs), it never really got past, "remember how annoying this mechanic was?  Me too!"  I found the characters and dialogue to be underdeveloped; after hearing the villian's backstory, I found them to be the most interesting character in the game.  The camera felt a bit claustrophic for me in the 3D sections; I would have liked to see an option to pull it away from the character, even a little.  Also, I know I mentioned this game was on the easy side, but most of the puzzles in the game involved exploring every inch of a given area rather than any critical thinking or problem solving; the only exception to this was the card battling (though even that could be made considerably easier with the right cards).  Lastly, I was disappointed with how the game treated its primary female protagonist (though I will not say more to avoid spoilers).With that being said, I did complete the game and gather all of the collectables.  At the end of the day, the core gameplay was enjoyable enough that it carried me through despite my critiques.  It also doesn't hurt that I was able to pick up the game for $1.99 from the Humble Bundle sale last week.  If I would have paid full price for the game ($9.99), I would have felt a bit cheated, honestly.

Posted: May 10, 2015
												I wouldn't get this unless it's on sale.Basically, it wants to be a love letter to Legend of Zelda, Diablo, and Final Fantasy, and there are parts of the game that ape all three.The Diablo part I can't speak for, because I've never played Diablo.The Final Fantasy parts are, frankly, bad. There's no real story here, just a small handful of jokey lines to remind you of plot points for Final Fantasy 7 and Secret of Mana, so right away this game is missing the main draw of jRPGs of that era, but it DOES pack in all the tedium of those games, including high random encounter rates and long, non-tactical fights which you win by just selecting the fight command a dozen times and watching the same canned animations over and over again.The Zelda parts fare better, and have one of the only interesting uses of the gimmick of moving forward through video game history: There are stones that block your path in 2d mode, but in 3d mode you realize that they're just 2d textures and you can walk over them. The puzzles in these sections aren't mindblowing but they're okay, and the bosses are tough but beatable. The Zelda parts are clearly where the majority of the development time went.A big problem is that nothing comes to a head; techniques and powers from one section don't cross over into other sections, and, because the different sections are all mixed together on the overworld, there's no way of knowing when you're completely done with one kind of section. I bought a bunch of potions for the final boss fight, but it turns out the boss fight is a Zelda section, so the potions were useless, because they only work in Final Fantasy sections. You'd think the boss would be a culmination of everything you've done, but nope, it's just a Zelda boss.$9.99 is too much for this game, it's just not polished enough. If you think you might like it and it's on sale dirt cheap you'll probably get something out of it, but if you're looking for a love letter to console RPGs you should get Half-Minute Hero instead.

Posted: August 18, 2015
												Evoland is an interesting game, not for its look, but for its gameplay.Much like the game "Life of Pixel", this game centers around evolving through different eras of video games. Unlike "Life of Pixel", this game is more Legend of Zelda/Final Fantasy/WoW in its RPG approach of gameplay (while LoP focuses on the aesthetic of specific video game consoles from the 70s-90s using platforming mechanics). Both games are great for nostalgia factor alone.If there are any nitpicks, I was a little disappointed in how sparse the story felt, but I didn't let that keep me from enjoying the exploring. I didn't care about the villain, but I did care about the environment and the exploration.When the game was first released, it was a little buggy, and some of the bosses' hitboxes didn't trigger, which made beating the game frustrating, but I am pretty sure that was resolved since I 100% this game a few months after. The act of collecting cards and playing a variation of FFVIII's Triple Triad card game is enough to get this. If not, then appreciate all the nods to your favorite retro games of yesteryear. No matter how you look at it, Evoland is a fun game. Give it a go, then brace yourselves for Evoland II, because it looks like everything the first game is, but better.

Posted: December 21, 2014
												Evoland takes a fantastic concept, the evolution of the action RPG, and plays it out with mixed results. The game begins in very simplistic 2D, but soon begins to play very similarly to the original top-down Legend of Zelda games (think Link's Awakening). After more time, the game progresses into full-blown 3D, more akin to PS1/PS2 Final Fantasy games, and even further onward to open exploration, like Diablo. There's all sorts of collectibles and monster encounters as you'd come to expect, and the package is hilarious and represents its source material very well.However, the game isn't without its faults. The transition to 2D to 3D is somewhat rough, and the game starts to lose a bit of polish there. Also, at all points in the game, hit detection can act oddly, leading to your character taking hits due to some wonky hitboxes, or in some cases, pushing your character through walls in a dungeon, leading you unable to continue without restarting. These problems are obviously very annoying, and make the experience worse overall.Would I recommend the game, given the balance of positives (nostalgic value, good design) and negatives (bad hit detection, suspect 3D game mode execution)? Yeah, but not at full price. The game is great for what it is, but it's short (the game takes 2-3 hours, maybe 4 if you are trying to collect everything), and the bugs can be very frustrating. Therefore, if you're interested in things like Zelda and Final Fantasy, be sure to give Evoland a look - if you can catch it for a large discount in a sale.

I knew when I bought this game it would consist of references to other games and a medley of existing mechanics, but i didn't know it would be stale, boring versions of popular games in history. As soon as you unlock jrpg-style battle sequences the game goes downhill - fast. Easily one of the worst executions of battle sequences I've ever seen, the whole thing seems neglected by the designer completely. you face battles every 5 seconds and it's completely repetitive and randomly unfair, I fought every creature I've come across and currently have the best gear but I'm still far to weak to survive a trip between my current town and the next. I can't use potions between fights so I have to waste my fight moves on them.Currently on my trip to get bombs, I'll likely get one fight with 4 monsters, before my first attack they accumulate about 30-45 damage on me, and a potion heals 50, I'm usually weak from the last few fights, if I run from them with less that 60-90 health (total 105) I may die from the 2 rounds of attacks they get. which leaves me with the strategy of using about 3 turns for just potions, until I can survive 2 consecutive rounds without healing, and either attacking a bee and missing or attacking a pirhana plant for just over half its health. Then I use 3 more potions, and try again. For me the last straw was common, unfair and uncreative fight sequences combined with the fact that theres no map, so you're walking in the wrong direction aimlessly, and then backtracking.The zelda style parts of the game are way better, more thought-out, and more fun than the fight sequences but even those aren't that good. Mages spawn right next to you and attack before evasion is even possible, skeletons need to be attacked from behind but are usually fixed on looking straight at you.zAll in all, it's not only a poorly executed game, it's, like, 4 of them.
