Posted: June 22, 2015
												Short version: I'm being snobby and wanted more of a deconstruction of classic games and less straight nostalgia.Evoland draws inspiration from old school RPGs, primarily the Legend of Zelda and Final Fantasy franchises. There is nothing inherently wrong with this, but it makes several gameplay mechanic choices that imitate limitations without considering why those limitations existed. In the action RPG (Zelda) sections where you directly control attack and movement, you are limited to only 1 active weapon and need to pause to switch between the sword, bomb, and bow. The original Zelda game had about a dozen useable items, but only 4 non-directional buttons to assign them to, hence the pause and switch mechanic. Evoland's implementation is mostly just an incovenience. For FF-style turn-based random combat (which, oddly, skips actual turn-based combat like the NES games used and goes straight to the Active Time Battle system of the SNES and PS era games), is pretty much devoid of options. Sure, old RPGs mainly just involved repeatedly selecting attack, but Evoland's protagonist has virtually no other options. There is a special attack that I still haven't unlocked over an hour into the game, and items, but I've only seen potions and phoenix down, which you rarely need as the enemies do almost insignificant damage. You gain an magic-using ally not too far in, who knows heal. About an hour in, she learns a basic magic attack. No elemental spells to exploit enemy weaknesses, no status effects, just boring vanilla damage. This spell makes her basic attack obsolete, as there is no MP stat, magic is free. Another issue I have with the game is that the FF-style inventory menu is completely non-interactive. You can't cast spells, look at a map, detailed character stats, or even look at item descriptions (much less use items). You don't even equip the weapons and armor you buy/find, it just automatically applies. Final gripe: in the town that first mimics Play Station era graphics, there is a disc loading delay between screens in the town as a little joking reference to the time. This joke quickly wears thin as the screen is about 2 seconds long, happens between EVERY screen in town, and then the game sends you on a fetch quest in town, repeatedly running from one end to the other. There is an in-game item you can buy to reduce the loading-screen, but I'm only assuming that because it costs more money than I had. I would have had to spend time grinding random battles, which would have taken longer than the time saved from the item.

Posted: May 25, 2015
												Since the game openly states that they got inspiration from Zelda and Final Fantasy, and after playing it it has become very evident that the game was much like these, this review will inevitably be more of a comparison between these. The Zelda elements were fun and recreated considerably well, with the exception of limiting you to only having one item to control at a time with the space bar. The puzzles were good, albeit a bit simple, and there was even some hand holding when it should have been obvious enough to figure things out. The Final Fantasy element just seemed stupid. The reason why I say this is that when you controlled the main character, he had 1 attack for 90% of the game. The secondary character had a heal ability and later received an attack which made the fights a bit less mindless, but for the most part the turn based combat was remarkably weak. The unlocking of RPG elements over time was cool, but the novelty was gone after a couple hours, and then the game turned into a Zelda/FF hybrid. I enjoyed the game for the mild Zelda fix it offers, but the Final Fantasy side was tedious, and the amount of game's length was a bit short (6.7 hours for me to do EVERYTHING). I'd say the game is worth it on sale for sure, but the game was too hit or miss for it to be worth full price for me.

Posted: May 10, 2015
												I wouldn't get this unless it's on sale.Basically, it wants to be a love letter to Legend of Zelda, Diablo, and Final Fantasy, and there are parts of the game that ape all three.The Diablo part I can't speak for, because I've never played Diablo.The Final Fantasy parts are, frankly, bad. There's no real story here, just a small handful of jokey lines to remind you of plot points for Final Fantasy 7 and Secret of Mana, so right away this game is missing the main draw of jRPGs of that era, but it DOES pack in all the tedium of those games, including high random encounter rates and long, non-tactical fights which you win by just selecting the fight command a dozen times and watching the same canned animations over and over again.The Zelda parts fare better, and have one of the only interesting uses of the gimmick of moving forward through video game history: There are stones that block your path in 2d mode, but in 3d mode you realize that they're just 2d textures and you can walk over them. The puzzles in these sections aren't mindblowing but they're okay, and the bosses are tough but beatable. The Zelda parts are clearly where the majority of the development time went.A big problem is that nothing comes to a head; techniques and powers from one section don't cross over into other sections, and, because the different sections are all mixed together on the overworld, there's no way of knowing when you're completely done with one kind of section. I bought a bunch of potions for the final boss fight, but it turns out the boss fight is a Zelda section, so the potions were useless, because they only work in Final Fantasy sections. You'd think the boss would be a culmination of everything you've done, but nope, it's just a Zelda boss.$9.99 is too much for this game, it's just not polished enough. If you think you might like it and it's on sale dirt cheap you'll probably get something out of it, but if you're looking for a love letter to console RPGs you should get Half-Minute Hero instead.

Posted: October 17, 2015
												A brilliant concept, executed poorly. Playing through the "history" of RPGs in one game, adding elements like improved graphics and a new gameplay mechanic when you find them in a chest sounds great, right? Soon you'll see that's all there is to the game. Levels and maps lack any design, merely leading you to the next "improvement", e.g. a switch to open that gate in the same room. Combat is dull, a single swipe in the "Zelda" style combat and basic Final Fantasy-turn based combat in the other. The character's movement is boring, walking and swiping whichever way you're facing, no jumping or running... unless that comes in much later in the game. And during those "Zelda" combat bits you better hope the enemy you want to attack runs directly into your sword swipe or you're going to be chasing them around the map for the next minute.It's an incredible shame this is what the developers came up with based on such a smart concept. They're working on Evoland 2 but I'm not optimistic for that game after what I've seen here. If only a talented dev had gotten ahold of this idea. That's the game I want to play.

Posted: October 27, 2015
												I wanted to like this game.  I really did.  Unfortunately, in trying to recreate the gameplay of much older games, Evoland captures most of their flaws and almost none of their charm.  Hit detection is awful, combat is boring, character movement is slow, and for a game that advances through increasingly "high-res" graphics, the final stage of graphic advancement is a disappointing, poorly-animated style that would feel more at home on an older smartphone than on a PC game.  This feel like a game the developers whipped up to learn how to program and then tried to sell on Steam.  Ultimately Evoland has some good ideas but very flawed execution.

Posted: October 27, 2015
												I was extremely skeptical about Evoland at first. I wasnt sure that it was the type of game for me, and honestly, it's not. But it has little bits of what kind of games I do like, rather looks and features. I would defenitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoys small, short, but entertaining. the pro's of this game. - the graphics are exactly what you'd expect. - runs smoothly, and have zero saving issues. - if you're someone that likes to save alot, there's alot of save points. - it's fun, fast, and definitely passes the time! The con's of this game. - the forced battles become a little too much, after a while, and could cause someone to quit just based off that. - when first playing, there was an issue with my controller being compatable, but is fixable. - the music is repetative, and im not personally one for it, but some don't mind it. - as your game gets more and more evolved, you'll notice if you have a dinky laptop like me, your computer tries to explode or shuts down every now n' again. again, solvable but not the developers issue.Overall: definitely recommended, regardless of the cons, and in my opinion, worth the price.

Posted: December 29, 2013
												I really wish I would have read the reviews before buying this game. Even on flash sale, I'm not sure it was worth the money, not even as an interesting experience, because quite frankly, it just wasn't.The idea is interesting enough, and you get the impression that it's going to be a unique game that gradually introduces you into new elements of gameplay as you progress. What it actually is, is a game that has you wandering around with no clear direction until you find some hidden (some not) treasure chest with an "upgrade" in it. Within the first hour, you're already in the 3D world, and you don't even have time to feel nostalgic before it's taken away from you. The pacing was just plain bad, and I feel like maybe if they had worked a bit more to make a longer game, it could have been more of a success.I read a review that said they use humor as a crutch, and I'm going to go ahead and second that. It really isn't that funny though, and it feels as if they tried way too hard to make a game that would appeal to players of old-school RPGs, without actually delivering anything that made them good.Overall, I feel like a lot of work was put into the game, but it just wasn't executed well. The graphics aren't bad, and they had to make several different sprites for everything, not to mention the 3D models, and the music is all very good. I acknowledge and appreciate that work, but I still can't recommend this game in good conscience. I'd give it maybe a 5/10.

Posted: May 31, 2015
												Evoland was the greatest barometer I could have ever had to let me know it was time for a new computer.A love letter to RPGs of days past, Evoland tells a story that's not really too important.  Beginning with a silent, black and white, pixellated game, you will slowly unlock more and more gameplay mechanics.  Rapidly, you will gain sound, the use of a weapon, and then color, and then improved scrolling, and then better color, and on and on.  The true joy of Evoland is the anticipation of whatever's going to happen next.  With my last computer, my clunky processor ground itself to dust trying to handle the 3D graphics as soon as I unlocked them, rendering me unable to complete the game until I upgraded to a dedicated gaming rig.You progress through a number of different gamestyles, and all of the familiar RPG tropes are lovingly shoehorned in.  There's Zelda-style dungeons, and areas featuring turn-based battles - even a Triple Triad-styled card game.It's best not to expect a grand epic adventure - it's just not here.  The speed of your upgrades peaks really early and then kind of flatlines a bit - one of the biggest criticisms of the game is it gets boring once the upgrades have been seen.  That's a little true, but things pick up a bit in a late dungeon that involves time travel.  Also, this game is very short, which is a plus in this case - it's enough to give you a taste of what you came for in the first couple of hours or so, and then coasts to a pretty quick conclusion.A lovely nostalgia trip.

Posted: May 3, 2014
Terrific Idea, Mediocre ExecutionEvoland purports to be a journey through the history of action/adventure gaming, but ends up being a nostalgic trip through A Link to the Past, Final Fantasy VI and Diablo.  Although I selected that I'd recommend this game, I'd really say that I'm closer to a "Neutral" than anything.Most of the game takes place either as an overly simple turn-based RPG or the beginning of a Legend of Zelda game.  Most of the mechanics are fairly simple:  In the RPG sections you attack, use items or cast magic (and there are only three magic spells in the game); in the Zelda sections you get a sword, bombs and a bow.  The few puzzles that exist are extremely simple, and the storyline is almost non-existent.Despite it being a simple game, Evoland is reasonably fun to play.  It's fun in the beginning to unlock new graphics types and abilities.  It also doesn't overstay its welcome...by the time it becomes apparent that the scope of the game is fairly small, it's over.  This is also a negative, however, as the entire game (including all of the optional achievements and getting 100% completion) can be easily finished in 4-5 hours.  If you can get it on sale (at least 50% off), it's a fun diversion for a few hours.  Just don't expect anything mind-blowing.Rating:  6.5/10

Posted: June 15, 2015
												A lot of people seem to have forgotten how to feel nostalgia for the sake of itself.Evoland is an absolute steal at this price (currently $2.49 at the time of this review).Evoland does a remarkable job of illustrating, in both sound and design, as well as function, the evolution of gaming from its inception on upwards. The only thing it does not illustrate is the brief period of time when graphics weren't even a thing, but very few of us would remember that era anyways, as it didn't last long.From the smallest of things as only moving in one direction, to transitioning to 8bit, 16bit, 32bit, 3D, etc graphics and beyond, it's like getting a history lesson in the most amusing way possible.The gameplay itself is reminiscent of Zelda, Final Fantasy, even a hint of CCG thrown in (there's a full-fledged miniature card game within the game itself once you reach a certain town). There are hidden items to find along the way, and the combat system changes with time as well. There are also a lot of interesting puzzles.I wouldn't call this game something you'll enjoy if you're looking for a huge challenge, or something incredibly fast paced or modern. This game was so obviously primarily designed to harken to days of old, so whether you're a younger individual who just wants to know or see what life was like while you were a toddler or not even born yet, or a seasoned game veteran looking for a nostalgia kick, this will be for you guys.And come on, who the ♥♥♥♥ complains about a $2.49 game?! I bought it back when it was $4.99 and the only reason I don't have more hours into it is because I have a backlog of waayyyyyy too many games to play (see Steam account, 90%+ of those aren't played fully, hah, but they are still worth every penny!).

Posted: January 2, 2015
												Evoland is probably one of the coolest ideas for a game I've seen.  When I first looked into this game however I was hit with tons of poor reviews on it, so I was hesitant to buy it.  This year's humblebundle sale had it really cheap though so I jumped in.  Evoland takes RPGs from early to recent and rolls them all into 1  crazy game.  Whenever you open a chest you never know what is going to happen.  Final Fantasy, Zelda, Diablo etc. are all referenced in this game, and generally in very humorous ways.  However it is not all good.  Though fantastic the game is rather short.  It can be beaten in about 1-5 hours, and several of the "evolutions" of the game come at you all at once so you go from NES level up to Final Fantasy 7 level pretty quick.   Also the game is known for being buggy.  I got stuck in a bug that left the game unplayable, by setting the airship down right next a forest that could not be exited from that side.PROsFantastic ideaVariety of graphics and gameplay updates throughoutOften hilarious upgrade notes and itemsSolid gameplay mechanics and combatCONsShort gameCan be very buggyLacks any kind of deep plotVery few sidequestsSimple item, magic and combat system leave little room for strategies.Overall I think this game is very much worth a play through at the right price.  I am very much looking forward to Evoland 2 and hope for a longer, more in depth story, with no game breaking bugs.

Posted: January 7, 2015
												First off, let me start off by saying that game is fun. It's fun, but is it worth your money? The gameplay is really interesting in that it literally evolves while your progress and the story is simple (reminder of really old school jRPGs), but feels incredibly forced and rushed near the end. Which most will reach within a couple of hours. The graphics are really pleasing and you can feel the effort that must have gone into making such a huge amount of assets, but you can't help, but feel that effort cut into the game's length/story. It also bothers me that the majority of the references felt like they were from the Final Fantasy series and you could easily pass off the game as a parody of it. I did get a couple of the other references (Diablo, League of Legends, Secret of Mana), but they were far and in-between the FF ones. I feel like with some better writers and longer gameplay  and the game could of been amazing, but even so if you find the game on sale, it's a really fun way to pass a day or two and satisfy that old school RPG hunger.The Rundown+ Unique and fun graphics+ Variety of different gameplay styles+ Features are unlocked as you progress in a fun way- Short Gameplay- Limited Replayability- Below average story telling

Posted: April 16, 2015
												This game is a lot of fun; it's a mixed bag when it comes to content because it chronicles many highlights of role-playing adventure game history. Starting with the basics and evolving graphically and mechanically as upgrades are collected, it never gets repetitive. There are many callbacks to famous entries in the genre, like The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past and Final Fantasy VII, so you may find yourself chuckling at the references from time to time. Overall, it's a really fun game that I'm glad I played. I would absolutely suggest giving it a shot if you have enjoyed role-playing adventure games in the past.

Posted: May 12, 2015
												Evoland could have gone in any of three directions - museum, satire, or video game. Ultimately it dabbles in all three, does not commit and succeed at any, and is an underwhelming experience.On the museum front, there are good periods where it shows the different stages of video games. At the beginning of the game these come by every 10 seconds or so and it's really just a gallery of different technical advancements without any exploration. These sometimes come in the wrong order (for instance, they leave "objective" until they've moved well into the SNES days, meaning that none of the earlier period had anything to play for other than exploration and technical advancement). After the first 20 minutes or so these museum developments slow way down and there are very few meaningful updates, alongside a veritable wealth of meaningless updates.As a satire, it shines in a few places. The dungeon crawler section has hilarious items with hilarious buffs. The first time in a village, the NPC conversations are spot on. Too often, though, it's sarcasm or weak humor and is never enough to sustain the game on its own.That leaves the "game". This was the greatest missed opportunity. Evoland does have a few highlights - the Zelda dungeon was simple but entertaining. There was a smart section with puzzles revolving around changing time periods. The majority of the game did not match these. As mentioned before, the opening 20 minutes play only as a museum, offering 20 seconds of walking and slashing before whisking you on. It misses an opportunity to recreate what made those old games great, birthing the genre. The Final Fantasy and Baldur's Gate style games rely heavily on skill trees and character development for entertainment, but Evoland omits these aspects in favor of satire, which, while funny, cannot carry the game through the long sections. Ultimately we're left with (too frequent) random encounters that offer no reward, a story that is even thinner than Final Fantasy I, and a game with too few bright points and too long of valleys between them.Hooray for the bright points, though!

												This game is a great homage to the very history of gaming. It makes countless references that are sometimes subtle and other times obvious to things like Final Fantasy, Zelda, and even Mario. While the story itself isn't perfect, the real catch of this game is the sheer enjoyment that you gain when opening a new chest and gaining something like breakable pots. I only had 2 problems with Evoland. The first problem is that you can only have 1 save file at a time and if you happen to choose new game and step on a save point then the whole game is lost from your original file. The other problem is that even though the game introduces several really cool elements to the gameplay, none of them stay long enough to really get used to them. Overall this game is great and even if it's not on sale, it's still worth it.

												Going into this game my expectations were not too high based on the negative feedback on this game. Some of it is warranted, as things like random battles are very frequent, to the point of being slightly annoying. They aren't difficult or frustrating though so it's not a showstopper. Posted: April 18, 2015
												THIS GAME IS ONE OF THE BEST GAMES I HAVE EVER PLAYED IN MY LIFE !Evoland, is a game that is meant to show the evolution of videogames, from the black&white, 2D, 8 bit graphics that make us remember about the old Gameboy Classic, up to the most recent technologies, that make videogames look as real as possible. But this game is not all about Evolution, you do not only search all over the map upgrades for your game, but you also have to focus on the storyline, which, I have to say is not bad. At all ! Posted: April 16, 2013
												This is a short and sweet run through the history of RPGs and adventure games. There will be many familiar elements to those of you who've played the Final Fantasy and Zelda series, especially FF6, FF7, and LttP. (And if you haven't, then what the ♥♥♥♥ are you waiting for, an engraved invitation? Seriously, they're amazing games.) There's even a section that plays like Diablo. The game starts out simply, with graphics that would be at home on the original Game Boy, and expands down the timeline of advances in game design and technology. Those of you who, like me, grew up with that progression, will appreciate this trip down memory lane.

Posted: July 7, 2014
												I don't recommend this, but only moderately. It has plenty of positives, but doesn't really offer much to the average gamer, even to the average RPG player. You would probably be better served just playing the games it copies (I say "copies" since I don't know how else to describe it, but I certainly don't mean the term negatively): The Legend of Zelda and Final Fantasy, especially. If you've played those (and Evoland mostly assumes you have), just play similar games that take themselves a little more seriously.Of course, Evoland is not a huge time sink: the whole thing will take 3 to 6 hours, depending on whether you speed through or try to find all the hidden items. It is shorter than it seems, though: the high random battle encounter rate and the tedious level design (which often requires you to go way around scenery obstacles for really no reason) drastically inflate how long the game takes. This is especially true if you want to do the optional goals, collecting cards and stars. The card game, which pretty much just copies Triple Triad from FF8, is pretty fun, but relatively easy and lacks replayability. The stars are pointless: they have no real purpose in the game, aren't explained, do nothing; the only real reason for them being there is to make another achievement and make the game seem like it lasts longer than it does.The MAJOR flaw with the game, though, is that it undermines its entire premise about halfway through. The "evo" part of Evoland is that you collect "upgrades" that let the game "evolve" from 8bit RPG mechanics and graphics to 3-D design and more recent mechanics. This was the most interesting part of the game, and makes the game valuable as a retrospective of the history of RPGS. About halfway through, though, you pretty much stop collecting any more upgrades. Indeed, the mimicking of other games just starts to happen randomly: the Diablo level is an example, where Diablo mechanics just show up and then go away after the level. Things stop to make much sense. Not that they do for the most part to begin with: often the sequence of upgrades makes no sense in terms of any real history of gaming "evolution." If the game would have stuck with the idea of evolution, making some of the earlier parts last longer (you move from 8bit to 3D very quickly, then get stuck in 3D for about 3 hours without the novelty of upgrades, making the story drag) and exploring the history of RPGs after FF8 (which is where it mostly stops), then it would probably be more interesting.Lastly, the story is just pointless. At first it's interesting as a parody of older RPGs, and then just becomes absurd. It stops working as a parody and gets cliche and doesn't even really seem to try. Since it's short, this may be worth playing if you have any interest in the history of RPGs or just like FF7. It is also a decent deal on sale. Overall, though, this is an interesting concept with woefully failed execution.

Posted: July 20, 2014
												I loved the concept of this game. I only wish it had been more focused in execution. The gameplay alternates between Zelda and Final Fantasy styles (and a tiny bit of Diablo). I get that the game is paying homage to these franchises, but the experience feels disjoint. For example, leveling up in the FF areas has no effect on your ability in the Zelda areas, and the health systems work completely differently as well. Ultimately, the game ends before you feel any sense of progress in either mode. It forgets what made these games fun.It was cool watching the game world "evolve" from monochrome 8-bit graphics to a modern cartoon style (although the concept runs out of steam too quickly, I think), and it has plenty of funny moments. Just don't expect too much substance here.

Posted: April 12, 2015
												Evoland is a journey through the history of video games. You start with no sounds, black and white, extremely pixellated, and can only move right. By the end, it's a fully working HD RPG. As you go through the game you'll find chests that when you open them, it'll give you something like "Move Left!" or "HD Backgrounds!" This game has the basics of Zelda-esque gameplay, turnbased gameplay, and Diablo-esque gameplay! Also, this game doesn't really take itself seriously, as the whole area where you play the game like Diablo, the loot is hilariously named, and hilariously defined ("+0.001% critical hit chance," or "+300 damage to walls and stone.") However, the further along you go, the more sophisticated the story gets, and it's actually not a bad story. Typical for games like Final Fantasy or Zelda, but not bad.Is this game good? Yes, but not all that long. Is the game worth the money? Absolutely. If you like good nostalgic hilarious RPG Zelda Diablo type things, then this game is definitely for you.

Posted: December 24, 2013
												I've been eyeing this game for a while now, and am happy to report that it was everything I hoped it would be.  Let's get the cons out of the way first...  the game is short.  If you rate a game based on the hours you get out of it, this probably won't be your cup of tea.  You can probably get through it with most of the colletibles in just a few hours.  Also, at times, the controls are a little frustrating.  This became most evident on the final boss, when I felt that most of my deaths were as a direct result of the way the controls handle (I was using an XB360 pad).  Now, on to the pros, which, I feel, FAR outweigh the cons.  As a long-time fan of RPGs, going back to the 80s, I felt that this game was designed as a humorous love song to those classic games of yester-year.  I strongly felt the influences of such classics as Zelda, Final Fantasy, with even a few visual references to Mario tossed in for good measure.  Evoland starts you off with a black and white, highly pixelated charachter, like something you might have seen on the original Game Boy, but quickly introduces new graphics, music, and gameplay mechanics, as you explore the progression of the genre over the years.  This is all done while playing through a largely generic story..but I feel that most people who will appreciate this game aren't playing it for the story, but for the nostalgia and fun to be had with this short gem.  In short, if you are looking for a great experience, I highly recommend this game.  The story is light, and though it is about RPGs, the RPG elements are thin, but the fun and progression of it makes it a great game to play through on your day off of work, or the weekend.  Give it a shot!

Posted: July 28, 2013
												A delightful little trip down memory lane, my only complaint is that it falls short in the fact that it emulates retro gaming a little TOO well!  If anything, this game made me remember why the stop-and-go pacing of JRPGs like Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest just didn't gel for me.  It always seemed like the combat was just getting in the way of the story!  Unfortunately, this game has very little story that is can actually be called compelling, so it's like all of the tedium with none of the payoff.  However, those setbacks did not stop the game from pleasantly surprising me.  All those complaints I made in the preceding paragraph?  The game knows all about them, but rather than trying to adapt those elements for a new generation, it celebrates them, shortcomings and all!  This game isn't about reinventing the wheel or even treading new ground, it's about reminiscing the past and paying respect to some of the greatest moments in gaming; the moments that defined gaming in the past, and without which we wouldn't have gaming as it today.  In that respect, this game succeeds.  It's a cheerful and lovingly-crafted tale of bygone days, and while the retro-style throwbacks in gameplay may confuse and fail to amuse the younger crowd, for us retro gamers it may spark some wonderful feelings of nostalgia.

Posted: May 15, 2014
												As other reviewers noted, this game isn't so much a journey of action/adventure games so much as it is a journey of RPGs--notably the Final Fantasy and the Legend of Zelda series. Which, admittedly, still promised a lot of fun and engagement, but didn't really deliver the way I'd hoped it would.It incorporates both old-school turn-based RPG combat and your older "hack-and-slack" style combat reminiscent of early Zelda games. However, these forms of combat alternate, so that most world-map combat is turn-based, and the majority of the dungeons and forests are subjected to the hack-and-slash that can be a little jarring in transition. The turn-based follows a familiar timer system, where you cannot attack, heal, run, etc., until it's your "time" to do so.While it admittedly did bring me a good bit of nostalgia, the game doesn't have much to stand on beyond that. As much as I found myself enjoying the ability to "unlock" the advancements to the game such as 16-bit color or 3-D rendering, it quickly grew tedious and monotonous. There's not a lot of story or plot to keep you interested in long term play, let alone to replay the game, and it doesn't have that something special to set it apart from other games, as it seems to rely to heavily on the nostalgia to carry the game. I did like some of the puzzles that had you switching between the 16-bit era and the more modern 3-D game structure to move through them, but it wasn't enough to make the game stand out.Furthermore, if you're looking to play this game purely through the keyboard and mouse, you'll be a bit disappointed. The space bar acts as the action key, and movement can only be achieved by your direction keys. It makes the older style combats (particularly your hack-and-slash) a bit more difficult to pull off with finesse. In the end, I can't really say I'd recommend the game--unless you have the time and money to kill, and don't mind enduring some frustration during gameplay to do so.

Posted: August 6, 2014
												Don't bother, it took about 3.5 hrs to beat the game start to finish and the only reason I show 5 hours played is because I started over at one point.  At first, it's a fun game, the concept seems like it should be entertaining.  But it plays on your nastalgia and does little else.  I had expected at some point that it might "evolve" into it's own game but that never happens and it is so short that the plot and character development may as well not even exist.  You will never care about the characters or what is happening in the world of Evoland.  It's a brief little trip down memory lane but that's all it is.  They basically just mashed a whole bunch of games together into one fast tracked, half♥♥♥♥♥package that never does anything as well as the games it was trying to copy (pay homage to, if you prefer).  If it's $1 - $2 on a steam sale maybe pick it up to kill a couple hours but DO NOT drop $10 on this game.  You will not get your money's worth.  The game just feels like a cash grab to me.  There is no effort at all to be original in any area of the game.  I understand that's part of the point of it.  To trek back through time and revisit all the old stuff you used to enjoy as a kid but at some point it should become it's own game or at least attempt to bring a half way decent plot to the table.  EDIT: You can buy Terraria, Binding of Isaac, Rogue Legacy, Starbound and so many other indie games for as much or cheaper and get SO many more hours out of them.  This just seems like a waste of money.

Posted: May 10, 2013
												Remember the days of Zelda?  Of Final Fantasy?  The makers of Evoland clearly do!  Whether you've been gaming since the 8-bit generation or somewhere beyond, this game is a delightful walkthrough of video game history, with all sorts of nostalgic winks and nods to "those in the know".  And if you're not?  Well, this is the perfect time to start, as Evoland gives you a fun guided tour through some iconic games and tropes.

Posted: April 5, 2013
												With just shy of 2 hours under my belt, I'm already enjoying the heck out of Evoland. The game starts with 8-bit retro-Gameboy-spinach-green graphics and allowing you to only walk right. That's it.  And from that point on it's up to you to evolve through gaming history in terms of features, sound, graphics, and gaming styles to make your way. The game makes me think, 'what will the next unlockable be?' as I explore and find chests that could hold the next upgrade, whether it be a new feature, an upgrade in graphics, or sound. Heck, a recent one allowed me to break jars finally with my sword. You'll also be taken through various RPG battle styles, keeping things a bit more fresh when on one moment you're battle 8/16-bit Zelda style, and next you're doing random encounters and battle menus like Final Fantasy. If you're a RPG fan, or a gaming fan in general, do yourself a favor and give Evoland a shot.

Posted: July 1, 2014
												Evoland is a neat concept that isn't executed very well. I lets you play through the history of RPGs flaws and all, plus some new flaws. The game ranges from mildly interesting, to boring to tedious. It's also probably the most unbalanced game I've ever played. You'll have random battles that completely destroy you, bosses that don't put up a fight at all, and a final boss that is more difficult than an Ys final boss on nightmare. The game is either way too generous or way too stingy with save points depending on where you're at in the game. It even has fake "load times" that you have to spend gil to get rid of. I finished the game but I wouldn't recommend it. If you can get it for a dollar or two it might be worth that, but even then there's better things to play.

Posted: July 1, 2014
												Fun game until the end. It's a game that does a good job of utilizing game mechanics from all our favorite console RPG games of old. By now, you probably know that it is a game that progresses through games like the Zelda and Final Fantasy series (at least the first several anyway). That's the highlight. The story is average, even the game-play throughout is merely average. Again, the highlight is the progression through all the many years of game development in a particular genre. Even then, though, this highlight becomes fairly tiresome about two-thirds of the way through the game. Bringing us to the end, where -- I won't say much about the story (it continues to be about average) -- the game-play submerges into an abysmal arcade frenzy that is full of bugs, lagging, and ultimately uninteresting style. Pick it up on sale for a few hours of fun; reminiscing of the beautiful games that propelled their successors to where they are today.

												"A Short Story of Adventure Video Game Evolution" indeed. Made short by cutting the story off around the Playstation era -- Evoland has devolved into a love letter to Final Fantasy VII long before Sephiroth kills Aeris. Err, before "Zephyros" kills "Kaeris," that is.And that love letter? It's from the creepy, overly-attached girlfriend. But THAT'S well apparent by the time "Clink" picks up "Claud's" sword and wades through the loading screens of the pre-rendered second town (Aogai) to meet with "Sid."The OTHER half of the game is split between nods to Final Fantasy VI and the pre-Gamecube Legend of Zelda games ... and a ham-handed Diablo parody. And I'm not particularly fond of what implies about the various Mario RPGs. Still ... there's worse ways to spend $10 USD, I guess?

Posted: December 28, 2013
												This game was really cool.  It started out where gaining chests would *evolve* gameplay such as improving graphics or fidelity mirroring the development of games within the last few decades but I wouldn't call this game a gimmick.  It had very fun puzzle mechanics later on in the game where you would travel between the 8-bit world and the fully developed 3D world in order to progress and it made gameplay very interesting.  The storyline is more of a tool than an actual story since gameplay and the story closely mirror FF7/Zelda but it is humorous at times.  Gameplay was pretty cool in that it featured all sorts of gameplay including a very sillly Diablo level featuring tons of gear for example a ring of item finding which had a description of "helps you find an actually useful item".  The bad parts I would say are the RPG gameplay sections which I feel don't develop enough, and the very short length of the game.Overall, it was a very fun game and I would buy it if it went on sale again if I were you.  You can really tell the developer put a lot of love into the game.

Posted: December 29, 2013
												The conceit is that you play through the history of RPG/Adventure games from the 80's until now all of which are built upon the world of Evolandia.  As you open chests, you unlock either collectibles or new game mechanics/visuals progressing through the era.At first I wasn't sure if it was satire or pastiche as the game didn't really have much to say about what it was putting before you.  There are a few in-jokes about RPG and Adventure characters, as well as a few familiar tropes in what is generally the barest bones of stories, and with the pace at which you discover new things early on the game can be amusing.  But at a certain point about halfway through the play time the game kind of just gives up and throws random game mechanics at you, taken from other games in the genres it references to be sure, but ultimately just kind of attached briefly and then discarded.My final conclusion about the satire/pastiche debate is that the game wants to be satire, mocking the genres it sets up, but it ends up being too fond of them and reliant upon them to actually critique them and instead just becomes a straight-up pastiche.  And that, unfortunately, is the tragedy of Evoland and why it falls flat on its face.  Rather than criticizing and attacking the failures of the RPG genre of the past, it reminds you of BETTER gameplay in some interesting one-off segments and then immediately buries you under everything you ever hated about RPGs.Random encounters?  Check.  Too many random encounters?  Check.  The inability to run from random encounters without getting your face smashed in?  Check.  Repetitive enemies?  Check.  The inability to automate these boring random encounters and go get a sandwich?  Check.  Pity, since Breath of Fire figured out automated fights back in the early 90's.But the game takes one extra step and gives you an inventory that is totally for show.  You can't equip weapons (fair enough, it's a short game), but you also can't use healing items or abilities between fights.  Which means if you just BARELY survive a random encounter, you better hope you get to a save point before your next one because otherwise it's right back to town.If it weren't for the fact that the game has you spending 50% of the time wandering the overworld map getting attacked every 4-5 steps, it could be forgiven for the utter, mind-numbing tedium you find yourself chained to.  Late in the game there's a decent modern-day RPG fight and the final boss actually has a bit of cleverness to him, but at this point if you didn't love everything about RPGs before you will probably hate the entire genre once and for all.I bought it for 2.50 and don't feel like my money was completely wasted.  But at a price point any higher than that, stay the heck away.

												What starts out pulling at the heartstrings of you childhood, ends in nothing but disappointment and disgust. The first hour or so of Evoland brings such hope and expectations only for them to be completely destroyed. It's worth it if its on heavy sale, but game has a total playtime of roughly 4 hours (full completion) so not worth paying full price.The concept is that as you progress through the game, you progress through the history of video game evolution, so I guess given the quality of most games today compared to the 'old' days, Evoland holds true to it's aim. It goes from dragging you in with aspects of the early FF and Breath of Fire like games, and ends simply mocking FF7 and FF8 from everything from names to events. Overall it gives the feeling that the developers were heavily interested in the game at start and by about the halfway point they just wanted to be done with it all.

Posted: December 29, 2013
												A charming walk from classic gaming to modern gaming - puzzles are mostly simple and people familiar with Zelda will find them pretty typical.  Very short and absolutely not worth full price - the nostalgia factor simply isn't enough to redeem slogging through random battles (at times) every 3 steps and dealing with slightly-off hit boxes in the top-down view, especially with fireballs and whirlwinds.  Other commenters have mentioned that unlocks slow down considerably after the first hour of play, and they are absolutely right.  Plenty of funny little references, but funny is not enough.  Expect about 3 hours of gameplay if you go looking for some secrets but don't go back for 100%.  It feels like there's a lot more they could have done - it's a pleasant diversion at $2.50 sale but I would have overpaid at anything more.

												Evoland is a small, yet enjoyable game. An easier and quicker game to 100%(achievement wise) than most, this game follows the "evolution" of video game development. Posted: December 23, 2013
												Evoland was a novel idea, but mediocre game. I’ve never played a game that has shined quite as bright at moments with such long stretches of uninteresting hours to separate the before mentioned shining moments. When I first bought and started Evoland I had nothing but the highest expectations for what the game was going to be. In fact I tend to have a positive bias and fondness to developers who participate in game-jams. Especially when they decide to realize those games as full fleshed out projects.  However the benefit-of-the-doubt flame that burned inside me began to get snuffed out fairly early into Evoland.Shiro Games (developer) creates a hero out of a young boy (no, really!?) who seems to need to purge the world of a darkness from what I could put together.  The game already had an innate humor to it, but they escalate the comedy through various items and achievements.  These moments although funny seem to get washed down by the endless amounts of grinding to the point of a random encounter every 2 seconds.  I could usually handle this, since I need them xp’s! However this becomes ever more frustrating when half the game you get to use it, and the other half switches between a Diablo-esque combat system and a Legend of Zelda style which is used far more for the puzzle style dungeons.With far too little story to keep my interested I quickly found myself losing interest.  Fortunately I was rejuvenated with the introduction of Evoland’s card game Double Twin.  Unfortunately I lost interest again once I had beaten the only man to play all the way through the Champion level with basic cards and no real reward for doing so.  We’re all suckers for rewards in these games. It makes all the bad wash away.Throughout the history of traditional style RPG’s there are two things I’m looking for as a player. The first being story. A good story can make me play through the most redundant and ridiculous gameplay just to get my fix. The second is gear.  I will play a game for hours on end just grinding if it means rare drops.  Evoland did neither of these for me, except in the Diablo-esque portion of the game.  Which happens to be my favorite part of the game. If you played the Evoland then you’d know that during the Diablo-esque point in the game you get loads of loot, all fake, all hilarious.Evoland consistently suffers from the need of to hold back. If only Shiro Games decided to have less restraint than Tom Green on speed Evoland easily would be worth the time and a huge recommend.  There are a few other issues, such as pacing and bugs, that even more absurd comedic elements wouldn’t allow me to overlook and give it an 8 or 9, but it’d be a realistic 6.The game also found itself contradicting itself with what you had unlocked and the randomness of switching gameplay mechanics at awkward moments only added to the overall games confusion. The only time this switching was explained or made sense was by the use of time altering crystals, which were used very appropriately as puzzle mechanics. These frustrating moments left me bewildered, wondering if I had missed something, or if the game really was just going to continue and contradict story.  What I mean to say, and to better explain, is that the game used chests to unlock different eras that were locked away by something evil.  If this were the case, why were certain areas not changing when I went back to them after I already had unlocked a newer era? Even switching between similar visual styles was jarring, and easily dismissed if they would have just put forth an effort to explain why.  With how outrageous this game could have been, all it would have taken is to make mention of some sort of barrier covering certain areas of the world restricting mechanics and graphics.  Possibly explained to you by a NPC, which there were far too few of as it was.To end this before I start beating the cliche’d horse (or is it already too late?) there is a lot of potential from the small French developer.  This game was a stepping stone.  If they learn from their mistakes I will be very excited to learn more about their newest title.Find this review and many others at www.PunchDrunkAlley.com

Posted: September 7, 2014
												The concept of the game is interesting. As the protagonist moves forward in his journey, the game itself evolves from 8-bits to 3D settings. The game tips its hat towards the fanbase of Final Fantasy and Legend of Zelda. Thus, one will expect to alternate between real-time combat to turn-based combat. However, the plotline is lackluster. An area is plagued by a villain and the protagonist has to defeat him. Players will be able to use a couple characters at their disposable, but there is no opportunity to upgrade one's weapons/armor. Leveling up doesn't seem to enhance one's offense. On average, the game can be completed within 3-6 hours.  Despite the cons, I try not to take this game too seriously. I haven't completed the game yet, but I could if I beat the final boss. At the moment, I am occupied with completing all the achievements. Double Twin is an enjoyable card game that can played within the game.

Posted: July 21, 2013
												Evoland is a must-play for any fan of the RPG genre. It will take you on a trip through memory lane, reliving all of your favourite games, from Final Fantasy to Zelda. You start off as an 8-bit game, and will constantly find treasure chests that will evolve the game's mechanics and the world around you. It will remind you of some of the great things about those games, but is not hesitant to point out their flaws too. Of course, Evoland is not without its own flaws, but this is a parody made out of love for the genre. The nostalgia, the tongue-in-cheek approach and the ever-changing world will make this a joy to play for RPG-fans, and will surely give them a warm feeling inside.

Posted: February 9, 2014
												This game is not so much a game as it is an experimental museum.It starts off with the most simple movement concept (left and right) displayed in almost black and white (see the first screenshot) and evolves gradually until it reaches a quite advanced level.Most ideas are directly "stolen" from other games and pulled off with a short comment.While it may not be a long journey (it will last a bit longer than two hours) it's definitely one of the best ways to showcase the evolution of video games.I like Evoland and can wholeheartedly recommend it - even if the admission fee of 10€ is quite steep.There simply is no game like it that I know of!

												Sick of cheap flash games that copy games such as Zelda? Well I certainly am. Now, young people/those who don't have any interest in such games don't be put off by what I just said. If you like a bit of nostalgia, or just love interesting games, then I would very much recommend this. Ok yes, sometimes it can be monotanous if you aren't very good at such games (Or just rusty in my case) due to rare autosaves, but it's an issue that didn't affect me. And with an almost puzzle sense thanks to hidden chests, you really do explore the detailed interesting levels. Once again, also thanks to a very enjoyable soundtrack, I'd really recommend this to those looking for a trip down memory lane, ot interested in something new

												What Jarin said, except that as one who did not play the old console games it was fun to go through that progression. I would love to see the developers take the positive and negative reviews and really dig into a solid "v1.0" release. The current version feels like a really good proof-of-concept or demo, but as a full game the lack of depth and innovation and very shallow game play become too apparent during the last 1/4 or so of the game. It is so important to finish strong and unfortunately, after a lot of initial promise, this one does not.And yet, for $10 I recommend this "game", but only just.

Posted: April 14, 2013
												"A Short Story of Adventure Video Game Evolution" indeed. Made short by cutting the story off around the Playstation era -- Evoland has devolved into a love letter to Final Fantasy VII long before Sephiroth kills Aeris. Err, before "Zephyros" kills "Kaeris," that is.And that love letter? It's from the creepy, overly-attached girlfriend. But THAT'S well apparent by the time "Clink" picks up "Claud's" sword and wades through the loading screens of the pre-rendered second town (Aogai) to meet with "Sid."The OTHER half of the game is split between nods to Final Fantasy VI and the pre-Gamecube Legend of Zelda games ... and a ham-handed Diablo parody. And I'm not particularly fond of what implies about the various Mario RPGs. Still ... there's worse ways to spend $10 USD, I guess?
